The excursion ends with a visit to a chilote family, where the traditional curanto is prepared for you; it’s a hearty dish of seafood, meat, potatoes and vegetables are piled high in a hole in the ground, buried and cooked among glowing embers.

dayInfo.title: Cross the Andes to Bariloche, Argentina.
dayInfo.description: Today you cross the Andes on a unique journey which passes through the mountains, following forested roads alongside a chain of glacial lakes. Your scenic drive winds its way towards Argentina, overlooked by towering, snowy peaks. On a clear day the conical snow-capped volcanoes offer a stunning backdrop to the turquoise, glacial waters on the lakes below. You arrive at Bariloche. This resort town is situated on the shores of Lake Nahuel Huapi, and was founded barely a century ago. It has a distinctive Alpine feel to it, and in winter it operates as a ski resort. There is a museum detailing the history of the native Tehuelche Indians and the story of the area’s colonisation.

dayInfo.title: Walks in the rugged hills around Lake Nahuel Huapi.
dayInfo.description: Included today are walks along trails climbing up through the mountains through woodland, with wonderful glimpses down over the lake through gaps in the trees. Spend your free time in cosy cafés savouring locally manufactured chocolate, or shopping for souvenirs. Out of town, venture along the lake-shore for sumptuous views of the forested mountains. There are some excellent walking trails including one which climbs Cerro Otto mountain. You may also wish to enjoy the panorama from the windows of the cable car which takes you to the summit (1,405m); here there is a revolving restaurant and splendid views as the sun sets over the mountainous landscape, dotted with forests and shimmering lakes.

dayInfo.title: Fly to Buenos Aires. Walking tour of the city.
dayInfo.description: Fly to the Argentine capital, Buenos Aires, an elegant and cosmopolitan city famed for the fascinating port district of La Boca with its cobbled streets and brightly painted houses. It was here that the tango was born, and Diego Maradona honed his footballing skills. The centre of the city is the historic heartland, with government buildings and churches as well as chic shopping districts, which have a nostalgic, Parisian feel. The bohemian district of San Telmo is full of quaint old houses interspersed with antiques shops, tango bars and expensive restaurants. Slightly further out of town is the Recoleta district, even more evocative of belle époque French and Italianate architecture. You will explore some of the most interesting parts of the city on a guided tour. Make the most of some free time to shop, have a drink and a pastry in a tea-room or peruse the items on display in one of the many markets. Explore the city’s splendidly renovated port district, Puerto Madero, which has trendy loft apartments, a string of open air restaurants and a small marina or discover the upmarket Palermo area with it’s trendy boutiques and fancy restaurants. If you want to visit one of the city’s iconic Tango shows speak to your tour leader who can arrange one for you for the evening.

dayInfo.title: Fly to Iguazú Falls. Excursions to the Argentine side.
dayInfo.description: Fly to Puerto Iguazú in the subtropical north-east corner of Argentina (2 hrs). The Iguazú Falls are unquestionably one of the most extraordinary natural wonders in the world. A total of 275 falls thunder through dense forest over a 2.5km stretch. The u-shaped Devil’s Throat is the main gorge, where the frothy water of the Iguazú River crashes over a 1.5km-wide precipice and columns of vapour are thrown skyward. Elsewhere the river flows decorously through the rainforest, breaking up into dozens of smaller falls. You might spot toucans with their outsized bright orange beaks perched in the foliage above the tumultuous waters. You have a guided tour to explore the Argentine side of the falls. From the National Park Visitor Centre, where there is a display that illustrates the biodiversity of the region’s tropical rainforest, a little natural-gas-powered train transfers you to Cataratas Station where the Upper Walk begins. This sequence of causeways and passarelles links dozens of tiny basalt islands at the top of a sheer rock face and the walkways cross the myriad streams of the River Iguazú as they cascade over the lip of the precipice. Your breath is quite literally taken away as the water thunders on to the rocks below. The train continues to Devil’s Throat Station where a 1km-long walkway leads across the river to the thunderous Garganta del Diablo, the Devil’s Throat. From this vantage point you can feel the incredible power of the water, and the flow is mesmeric as it plummets into the vortex below.

dayInfo.title: Excursion to the Brazilian side of the falls.
dayInfo.description: Head out to the Brazilian side of the falls, from where there is a broad panorama of these magnificent cataracts, and some excellent opportunities to photograph the full sweep of the cascades. Before leaving the Brazilian side, you could stop off at the excellent and rather quirky bird park just outside the entrance of Iguaçu National Park. The enclosure is home to a huge variety of birds and wildlife, including toucans, trogons and the coatimundi, from the same family as the racoon.

dayInfo.title: Fly to São Paulo; by road to Paraty.
dayInfo.description: Fly to São Paulo and continue by road to the colonial port of Paraty. The winding road is bordered by steep mountains covered in lush Atlantic forest on one side, and the ocean on the other. This enchanting bay-side town is steeped in history; Paraty, means ‘river of fish’ in the indigenous Tupi language. The town is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and it’s not hard to see why as you wander through its local boutique-lined cobbled streets. Explore graceful baroque churches and check out the local art work in one of the many contemporary galleries. The divine blue, gold and white painted Portuguese architecture has been carefully preserved, and the centre of the town is vehicle free. There are also some excellent places to eat freshly caught fish on the sea-front. The bay itself is dotted with tropical islands and, rising some 1,000m behind the town, are forested mountains intersected by rivers and waterfalls.

dayInfo.title: Excursion by traditional schooner around the bay.
dayInfo.description: Travel out to sea in the sheltered bay on the deck of a traditional three-masted schooner. You’ll visit some of the virtually uninhabited little islands in the bay, each with its own hidden picture-perfect sandy coves where you can take a dip in the warm tropical waters.

dayInfo.title: By road to Rio de Janeiro.
dayInfo.description: A scenic drive up the ‘green coast’ to Rio de Janeiro. Rio is the most romantic, intriguing and beautiful city on the continent. Sumptuous apartments overlook the sparkling bays against the backdrop of half-built slum dwellings, favelas, which cling precariously to the hillsides. Rio has an awesome bay-side location among near-vertical granite mountains. Here, tropical foliage swoops down to white-to-toffee coloured sandy beaches in turn battered by the huge waves of Atlantic surf. The drive into the city gives a fleeting glimpse of the docks and commercial centre as you head towards the magnificent stretch of sand at Copacabana; your hotel is a couple of blocks inland from the beach.

dayInfo.title: City tour including Corcovado and Sugarloaf mountains.
dayInfo.description: Today there is a tour to familiarise yourself with this most iconic of cities. As part of this, you’ll board a steep rack-and-pinion railway which glides up through tropical Tijuca National Park, the largest urban forest in the world dripping with fruit and flowers, to reach the summit of Corcovado Mountain. Here the famous 40m art deco Christ the Redeemer statue soars above the city, arms outspread benevolently. On a clear day, the views over the city and out across the ocean and outlying islands are stupendous. We also include a trip to Pão de Açucar (Sugar Loaf Mountain). Ride the cable-car up the twin granite mountains protruding from the ocean and enjoy the magnificent views back over the beaches, Botafogo Bay with its bobbing yachts and into the mountains beyond. There’s a lovely (and safe) nature walk round the foot of the mountain, or you could pop for a beer into the nearby villagey quarter of Urca, leafy home of artists and TV stars.

dayInfo.title: Depart for international flight or extension.

tourName: El Calafate & El Chaltén holiday, Patagonia
generalInfo: Discover the wonders of Patagonia on this 7-day journey through El Calafate and El Chaltén. Begin by exploring the awe-inspiring Perito Moreno Glacier, combined by an authentic experience at a traditional Patagonian estancia. In El Calafate, you’ll also enjoy a thrilling bike tour through the vast, scenic Patagonian steppe. Then, head to El Chaltén, where your accommodation is nestled in a stunning natural setting. From here, you can embark on unforgettable hikes, surrounded by breathtaking landscapes, or simply relax and soak in the beauty of this unique wilderness.

dayInfo.description: Take off for El Calafate and the glacier region! As you land, keep an eye out for the chance to catch a glimpse of Lake Argentino right next to the airport. Upon your arrival, you will be transferred privately to your hotel. Built on the southern shore of Lake Argentino, El Calafate is the main gateway to the southern area of Los Glaciares National Park and the incredible Perito Moreno Glacier. It is located on the shores of Lake Argentino, in the province of Santa Cruz, about 80 kilometers from the Perito Moreno Glacier and 2,800 km from the city of Buenos Aires. At the end of the day, you will be welcomed into Gabriel’s home for dinner, a cozy place where you’ll feel right at home in the heart of southern Patagonia! Night in Posada los Alamos or similar

Guided departure from El Calafate along the old Route 15, the "estancias trail," which connects different stories of Patagonia: indigenous peoples, pioneers, and inhabitants. Once inside Los Glaciares National Park, at the end of the road, you will reach Estancia Nibepo Aike where all the stories converge. There, where over 100 years ago the first settler arrived, there is now an estancia dedicated to cattle, sheep, and horse breeding. You will tour its pens and sheds, where you will witness a demonstration of manual sheep shearing. In the Quincho of Estancia Nibepo Aike, a typical Patagonian lamb barbecue is served, accompanied by salads, desserts, and beverages included. Then, a walk is taken to the Pioneers' pier, from where navigation begins on the South Arm and Rico Arm of Lake Argentino. Disembarkation at Monedas Beach, accessible only by boat. A 40-minute walk is made, allowing you to appreciate the native forest, where wild cattle still remain, remnants of the ranching era before these lands were declared a National Park. The trail penetrates the Lenga forest until the Perito Moreno Glacier is spotted through the foliage. Upon leaving the forest density, you will descend towards the Sur Glacier viewpoint: a rocky beach with privileged views. Back on board, the navigation travels along the southern face of the Perito Moreno Glacier. Opportunity to observe the ice detachments and appreciate how its front approaches the Magallanes Peninsula, sometimes mounted on the rock, thus forming a natural dam. Disembarkation at Bajo de las Sombras port, to access by land to the walkways located 6 km away. The tour starts from the highest point, with a panoramic view, and then descends towards the Tempanos Channel. Throughout the tour, you will admire the magnitude of the glacier from different angles. After spending more than an hour on the walkways, you will return to El Calafate by vehicle at sunset. Lunch included. Small group activity, with English/Spanish-speaking guide Park entrance included Note: In case of total or partial impossibility of navigation, an alternative plan is implemented for accessing the Perito Moreno Glacier from Estancia Nibepo Aike by land, and if possible, navigation is made in front of the Glacier. Night in Posada los Alamos or similar

Bike Ride through the highlands of the 25 de Mayo Natural Reserve, where you can experience Patagonia in all its splendor, marveling at the landscapes and animals that inhabit these lands. Departure from El Calafate in 4x4 vehicles heading south, through the Calafate Creek valley. After a 15 km ascent, you will reach the 25 de Mayo Estancia section, where MTB bicycles await you. After the technical briefing, you will embark on a bike tour that will allow you to spot a wide variety of fauna: guanacos, foxes, choikes, condors, and eagles. Crossing the Guanacos Valley and with a breathtaking view of the Verlika and Baguales hills, you will reach a chenque (ancient Tehuelche burial site) where you will stop to rest, hydrate, and contemplate the vastness of Patagonia. Finally, you will return to La Seccion, where lunch or dinner awaits you before descending to El Calafate in a 4x4 vehicle. Distance covered: 50 km. Distance covered by bike: 16km (2 hours). High difficulty. Elevation gain: 200 meters. Minimum age: 12 years. Departure 9:00 AM. Duration 5 hours. Includes: lunch with drinks (cheese platter, lamb stew in country bread, chocolate mousse) Night in Posada los Alamos or similar

A bus transfer will take you from your hotel in El Calafate to your hotel in El Chaltén. It takes around 3 hours to get to this village. El Chaltén, located in Argentine Patagonia, is known as the "National Capital of Hiking." Surrounded by imposing peaks and majestic glaciers, it is the starting point for exploring the Glacier National Park and enjoying spectacular mountain trails. Its pristine landscapes and tranquil atmosphere make it a paradise for hiking and nature enthusiasts. You will stay in a private natural reserve located 27 km from Chaltén, on provincial route 23, in the Río de las Vueltas Valley, province of Santa Cruz, Argentina. At Refugio de Glaciares everything is covered, everything is taken care of, from transfers to and from El Chaltén, accommodation with breakfast, meals, and guided walks along their trails. This lodge is carbon neutral and offsetting the ecological footprint of all the visitors is their aim. They have internet service with pre-established schedules. On this day, you can already do a short hike to el Rio de las Vueltas. On a flat plain, 5,5 km of footpaths allow you to enjoy the beautiful winding river, full of beaches and bends. With 360-degree views, it is possible to enjoy the best-known sceneries of the area. This is a circuit that begins and ends at the Lodge, crossing two bridges that allow us to appreciate the amazing color of the water. Walking time: 4 hrs. Total distance: 5.5 km round. Slope: 50 m Dinner included Night in Refugio de Glaciares

Wake up in this amazing and relaxing setting. Enjoy your day to walk to the Cagliero Glacier. As you leave the Lodge, the first section of the walk is through 1,50 km of lenga forest, and flat terrain until you reach the crossing of the Del Puesto Creek. From there, the second stretch starts with a slight ascent bordering Del Puesto Creek for another 2 km up to the Pink Lagoon prairie, a wetland that is home to stable populations of great biological and conservation value, which will be explained by your guide. On the third and last section of the walk, you will keep bordering the lagoon for 800 more meters, getting close enough to the imposing Cagliero Este Glacier to contemplate hanging glaciers and moraines, truly a sight to be in awe of the geological shapes that time has been sculpting. After lunch and this unforgettable memento of wonder, you will return to the lodge. Walking time: 5.30 hs. Total distance: 8km round Slope: 250m All meals included Night in Refugio de Glaciares

Get ready to live the most famous hike in El Chaltén. In a transfer and pre-established time, transfer to the entrance of the path that leads to Laguna de los Tres. This hike is one of the most beautiful in the area and starts at the end of the main street, San Martin, after the parking lot. A sign "Senda el Fitz Roy" indicates the starting point. You will then have a 10.2 km (approximately 5 hours, excluding stops) hike to reach the final destination. After a final ascent, you will be there! You'll be at an altitude of 1,170 meters. Mount Fitz Roy will emerge in front of you, and a turquoise blue lake will stretch at your feet. The trail is fully marked and well-maintained. Another option is to take the transportation to Hostería el Pilar. From there, you start towards Laguna de los Tres, taking a different trail than the return route. You will arrive at the viewpoint of Glacier Piedras Blancas, which starts from the Rio Blanco bridge and involves an 800-meter elevation gain. Continue your path towards the Poincenot campsite, towards Laguna de los Tres, and from there, begin your return to the accommodation passing by Laguna Capri. This way, you avoid 2 km and get to admire another trail. Important: The last kilometer to Laguna de los Tres is of difficult difficulty. It is a steep and rocky ascent that takes approximately 1 hour to complete. Total round trip: 20 km - Approximately 9 hours. Return to Refugio de Glaciares at a pre-established time. All meals included Night in Refugio de Glaciares
Transfer to El Chaltén From there, you take the bus to El Calafate Airport. End of our services

tourName: Grand tour of Patagonia holiday
generalInfo: This is a journey to the extreme territories of Patagonia, both in Argentina and Chile. In this full itinerary you will be able to visit the capital city of Buenos Aires and meet the wildlife of Peninsula de Valdes, with an overnight stay in the suggestive lighthouse of Punta Delgada. Time to drive along the Chubut valley, you will be surprised by the importance of the local Welsh community. The winding scenic roads of the Lake District will offer a beautiful setting to your self-driving experience. Once in Chile, with a border crossing through the Andes, you will drive to Puerto Varas, surrounded by glacier lakes, green forests and snow-capped volcanoes. Finally, visit the two most visited National Parks, Torres del Paine in Chile and Los Glaciares in Argentina with its famous Perito Moreno Glacier. Fly back to Buenos Aires.

dayInfo.description: After landing in Buenos Aires, you will be met at the airport by your driver and transferred to your hotel in the city center. A member of TransHumans will meet you at the hotel to offer you some advice as well as providing you with the Road book and SIM card to be in contact with us if needed. Wander around the capital city, soaking up the atmosphere and visiting the most picturesque areas: El Caminito and San Telmo, at the origins of Tango, then the ancient harbor, heart of the city. At night, take a walk in Puerto Madero area, an old harbor reconverted into a business area. Transport: Private transfer 1h >Accommodation: Hotel (Buenos Aires) >Included meals: none

Today you will drive south to Punta Tombo for a self-guided excursion to this Natural Reserve. This is the most important penguin colony in the Americas, a rocky strip 3.5 km long by 600 m wide extending seaward. Penguins arrive every year to this place to nest and mate, before making the journey back and returning the following year. Optional: before driving north to Puerto Madryn, you could reach the Port of Rawson and from there go on a 1 ½ hour navigation to see the Tonina dolphins (black and white). Transport: rental car 80 miles ~ 2h30 to Punta Tombo + 115 miles ~ 3h30 to Puerto Madryn > Accommodation: Hotel (Puerto Madryn) >Included meals: breakfast>Excursion to Tonina Dolphins not included (~ USD50)

Today you will drive to Peninsula Valdes wildlife reserve, a huge maternity ward for whales, penguins, sea elephants and lions among others. To reach the park you will have to go through the isthmus and then drive to Puerto Piramides, about 70 miles away, the starting point for your whale-watching tour. Whales arrive to Peninsula Valdes to mate and give birth to their calves. Tonight, we recommend you to spend the night in the Peninsula. Faro Punta Delgada is a simple hotel in a beautiful setting, an old post office, with its own lighthouse and surrounded by cliffs. Some activities available around the Hotel (guided walk in the Estancia, wildlife spotting and stargazing). Transport: rental car 100 miles, depending on the itinerary > Accommodation: Hotel (Peninsula Valdes) > Included meals: breakfast and dinner >Whale watching navigation included (subject to weather conditions) ~ 1h30

Enjoy the morning in this beautiful part of the peninsula. At a convenient time, you will leave for Caleta Valdés to observe sea elephants and lions, Magellan Penguins and possibly killer whales. In the late afternoon, you will drive back to Puerto Madryn. Transport: rental car ~ 100 miles depending on the itinerary > Accommodation: Hotel (Puerto Madryn) > Included meals: breakfast

In the morning, leave Puerto Madryn to start driving along the winding Rio Chubut on the Ruta 25, accompanied by high cliffs which ignite at sunset. This is the land of the legendary Tehuelche. Your final destination for the night is Los Altares in the Valle de los Altares (Altars Valley), a splendid ravine reminiscent of the Jurassic period. You will drive through various sites which used to be dwelled by the Welsh pioneers along what used to be the central Chubut Railway (Ferrocarril Patagonico) which operated from 1888 to 1961. Spend the night in a motel managed by ACA (Automovil Club Argentina) Argentina’s largest automobile association. Transport: rental car 220 miles ~ 6-7h > Accommodation: Hostel (Los Altares) > Included meals: breakfast

In the morning, leave from Los Altares to Tecka and finally Esquel where you will spend the night. You will continue along the Ruta 25 through the Argentinean Pampa until reaching the last backwater town of Tecka. In the distance, the Andes mountain range... Another 60 miles along the famous RUTA 40 and you will be in Esquel. About 20 miles before reaching Esquel you will come to a junction with Ruta 14 an off the beaten track route to Piedra Parada* (Standing Rock). Recommended stop! Esquel is a small Patagonian city embedded in a rough landscape, where the Patagonian steppe merges with the Andean forest. Here, the history and traditions of the Mapuche and Tehuelche peoples mingle with the saga of the Welsh settlers. Close to Esquel, Los Alerces National Park undoubtedly one of the best in Argentina. Overnight in Los Alerces National Park totally recommended. Transport: rental car 200 miles ~ 5h >Accommodation: Hotel (Esquel)>Included meals: breakfast

In the morning, you will leave for Bariloche, in the lake district. You are scheduled to arrive there in the late afternoon. Bariloche is the main town in Argentina's lake district, on the southern shore of Lake Nahuel Huapi. You could spend the rest of the day enjoying the area surrounding your beautiful hotel, located in the San Pedro peninsula. Transport: rental car 180 miles ~ 4h > Accommodation: Hotel (Bariloche) >Included meals: breakfast

Today we would recommend a visit to either the Cerro Campanario view point or Cerro Catedral ski resort for superb panoramas over the lakes and mountains. Bariloche is also a good base for scenic lakeshore drives and your hotel is perfectly located nearby. Today you could enjoy the Llao Llao peninsula with walking trails and picturesque drives around Lago Moreno. Transport: rental car / depending on route> Accommodation: Hotel (Bariloche) >Included meals: breakfast > Trekking: easy hikes /depending on trails

Today you could drive along the famous 7 lakes route, running north from Villa Langostura to San Martin de los Andes. The Ruta de los Siete Lagos (7 Lakes Route) travels past seven main lakes that look spectacular amidst snow-capped mountains and forests. Running through both the Lanin and Nahuel Huapi National Parks, this route is completely paved. Whilst there are lots of deviations off the main path, many of which are unpaved, the direct route is 110km in length and it can take as little as 1.5 hours to travel. Multiple stops will increase the travel time significantly. Throughout the day, you will stop at different viewpoints with various detours and hikes. Spend the night in San Martin de los Andes. Transport: rental car 70 miles OW / depending on route > Accommodation: Hotel (San Martin de los Andes) > Included meals: breakfast >Trekking: easy hikes /depending on trails

In the morning you could reach the Arrayanes lookout for beautiful views over Lake Lascar and San Martin de los Andes. Today we recommend you to do the big circuit to Villa Traful, through thick forest, strange rock formations and a stunning scenery, bordering the Limay River. Just like the previous day, you will stop at different viewpoints with various detours and hikes. In Villa Traful, you could rest on the lake shores or go hiking to the small Cao Cò falls, a nice trail under the shady trees of the forest (coihue and ñire). Alternatively, you could spend the night in Villa La Angostura. Transport: rental car 80 miles OW unpaved /depending on route >Accommodation: Hotel (San Martin de los Andes) >Trekking: easy short hikes / depending on trails

Today you will leave Argentina to cross over the Andes all the way to Puerto Varas, in the Chilean Lake District. Head to Cardenal Antonio Samoré Pass, only about 20min drive from Villa Langostura. Leaving behind the Nahuel Huapi N. P., Argentine oldest National Park, you will reach the border between Chile and Argentina, at a height of 1314mts. After passing border controls, you will enter the jungle-like landscapes of the Valdivian humid woodlands, through the Puyehue National Park. Take you time to enjoy the scenery, stopping for lunch and finally get to your lodge over Lake Rupanco, with nice views over the Osorno and Puntiagudo Volcanoes. Spend the night in Puyehue. Transport: rental car 125 mi ~ 6h (depending on border crossing) >Accommodation: Hotel (Puyehue) > Included meals: Breakfast

Wake up in Chile’s Lake District, a green region, famous for its mystical quality. Today you will drive to Puerto Varas. This charming town is located on the shores of Llanquihue Lake (Chile’s second largest), framed by two snow-capped volcanoes, Osorno and Calbuco. In addition to the gorgeous scenery and lots of outdoor activities, the area’s diverse history provides a unique mix of culture. Once inhabited by the indigenous Huilliche people, the region was conquered by the Spanish in the 1540s. Later, in the 1850s, German settlers from Hamburg began to put down roots. As a result, many of the geographical names are in the Huilliche language, some of the area’s biggest attractions are hundreds of wooden churches built by Spanish Jesuit missionaries, and the architecture in several areas is distinctly German. On the way to Puerto Varas, we recommend you to stop at the lakeshore town of Puerto Octay, a charming town with a beautiful German-style architecture and the town of Frutillar, with streets lined with flower gardens and perfectly-maintained wooden buildings Transport: rental car 80 mi ~ 4h >Accommodation: Hotel (Pto Varas) > Included meals: breakfast

Leave in the morning to reach Parque Nacional Vicente Pérez Rosales and Petrohue Waterfalls. These spectacular waterfalls of Saltos de Petrohue are at the foot of the imposing Osorno Volcano in the Andes Precordillera. This Park also offers different treks that vary in terms of difficulty. Three of the treks can be completed in one day or less: the “Trek El Rincon,” which involves hiking along the base of Volcán Osorno through ancient landslides and native forests; the “Desolation Pass Trek”; and the Trek Paso los Pumas,” a full-day adventure that includes boating across Lago de Los Santos, crossing creeks and walking through a valley of endangered alerce trees. If you feel adventurous you could go white-water rafting on the Petrohué River or just kayaking on Lake Llanquihue back in PuertoVaras. Transport: rental car 40 mi ~1h30 > Accommodation: Hotel (Pto Varas) >Included meals: breakfast > Self-guided trekking: depending on treks

Today is your last day in the lake region before moving to the southern part of Chile. You might want to relax in your hotel, wander around Puerto Varas and Lake Llanquihue. Alternatively, we could recommend you some nice excursions, including the alerce forests, with deep valleys, lakes and lagoons. Transport: rental car : depending on chosen activities > Accommodation: Hotel (Pto Varas) > Included meals: breakfast

In the morning, you will head for Puerto Montt airport where you will return your rental car before boarding a flight to Punta Arenas. Once arrived in Punta Arenas, a private transfer will take you to your hotel in Torres del Paine National park. This is the perfect place to relax and unwind. A region of great beauty, with a diverse variety of plant and animal species, breath-taking scenery and wild geography. It is also an ideal place to enjoy some unforgettable trekking. Transportation: private transfer 200 miles ~ 5h > Accommodation: Hotel (Torres del Paine) >Included meals: breakfast >Entrance to the Park not included (~ USD35)

Today you will wake up in Torres del Paine National Park. Take some time to enjoy your hotel, located on the shores of Lake Grey. While in the Grey sector, we recommend you to enjoy a cruise over LAKE Grey, lasting about 3 hours, reaching Grey Glacier’s face. The blue-coloured ice and jagged ice peaks are simply amazing. In the afternoon, you could stroll around the lake or, if you feel like it, you could hike to Mirador Monte Ferrier for some amazing views (challenging ascent - 6 miles ~ 5h). THE TREK CAN BE SELF-GUIDED OR WITH A BILINGUAL GUIDE (~ USD 60 p.p.) LAKE GREY CRUISE (~ USD 100 p.p.) Accommodation: Hotel (Torres del Paine) >Included meals: breakfast >Guided hikes and cruise not included (minimum number of pax applies to the cruise)

Today, you will be transferred to the north side of the park, to hotel Las Torres. Ideally, before moving to your next accommodation, you will visit Salto Grande waterfall half way between the two hotels. This is a relatively easy excursion taking you to this spectacular waterfall and an astonishing viewpoint. The excursion starts with a 45-minute drive to Pudeto in the heart of the park’s lake district. From there a trail will lead you first to Salto Grande then to Mirador Cuernos, possibly the Park’s most spectacular viewpoint, offering views of the “Horns” (Los Cuernos), Mount Paine Grande and the French Valley and Glacier rising straight up from the the other side of Lake Nordenskjöld. (3.7miles ~ 2h). At the end of this excursion you will reach hotel Las Torres. BILINGUAL GUIDED TOUR (~ USD 100 p.p.) Transportation: private transfer 45 mi ~ 1h30 > Accommodation: Hotel (Torres del Paine) > Included meals: Breakfast > Guided hikes not included

Today you will continue to enjoy the beauty of the park, waking up in a different part of the park, in Hotel las Torres. In the afternoon, we recommend you a short hike, part of the famous “W” trails, that stretches between the Lake Nordenskjold gorgeous north shore and the hanging glacier of Monte Almirante Nieto (4.3miles ~ 1h30). This can be easily done on your own. THE TREK CAN BE SELF-GUIDED OR WITH A BILINGUAL GUIDE (~ USD 100p.p.) Accommodation: Hotel (Torres del Paine) > Included meals: breakfast >Guided hikes not included

If you feel ready for a real adventure, you could set out on a full-day hiking to the base of Paine Towers (aprox. 8h – 11 miles return). You would need to leave early from your hotel, follow the trail, through a millenary Lenga forest to the base of “the moraine”, then a challenging 45-minute ascent will take you to one of the most impressive lookouts in the park, the famous Base of Torres del Paine. Please note that the last part of this trek is extremely rocky which might have an impact on your knees, with parts featuring steep drop offs than may induce vertigo. Otherwise there are plenty of half-day guided excursions to choose from (Laguna Azul – amazing views with little walking; Lenga Forest – 5-mile hike among Nothofagus trees; Rock Paintings – 4-mile hike to a rock formation with paintings from the ancient Aónikenk people of Patagonia). TREKS WITH A BILINGUAL GUIDE (from ~ USD 60 p.p.) Accommodation: Hotel (Torres del Paine) >Included meals: breakfast >Guided hikes not included

Leave in the morning to return to Argentina. We recommend you a private transfer from the Park to your hotel in EL Calafate. After crossing the border, you will arrive to the Argentine pampas with ñandus and guanacos. Spend the night in El Calafate. Transportation: Private transfer ~ 5h > Accommodation: Hotel (EL Calafate) > Included meals: breakfast

Leave at 7:15am from your hotel and start a cruise on Lake Argentino and its calm blue coloured waters. The navigation runs between fjords and floating icebergs of spectacular size and forms. Finally, you will approach the majestic fronts of the Glaciers Upsala and Spegazzini. Return to El Calafate at the end of the afternoon. Transport: Bilingual group service + Cruise on Lake Argentino ~ 6 h > Accommodation: Hotel (EL Calafate) >Included meals: breakfast >Entrance to the park not included ~ USD 25

Experience the famous Perito Moreno Glacier. This is the most active glacier in Patagonia and with some luck you will hear the terrible cracking noise and possibly observe a massive block of ice falling into Lake Argentino. Depart from your hotel for the Los Glaciares National Park following the old road that borders the lake. Stop just a few kilometres from Perito Moreno glacier to enjoy a short hike to admire the glacier along the arm of Lake Rico. Inside the park, reach the main observation point and later enjoy different perspectives of Perito Moreno from the many viewpoints. Enjoy this amazing show of ice from up-close. Back to El Calafate by the conventional route. NAVIGATION (~ USD 100 p.p.) Transport: bilingual speaking group service> Accommodation: Hotel (EL Calafate) >Included meals: breakfast >Entrance to the park not included ~ USD 25

Time to leave Patagonia Transfer to El Calafate airport to board a flight to Buenos Aires. Private transfer to your hotel. Free time in the capital. Transportation: transfer 30 min x 2 > Accommodation: Hotel (Buenos Aires) > Included meals: breakfast

Another day for you to continue exploring Buenos Aires. You can choose to take a walk downtown to the Pink House (Government) and Congress, or enjoy the parks and nice buildings of Recoleta and Palermo. In these neighbourhoods, you will find interesting museums as well as Plaza Francia, with its craftsman fair and Tango dancers. Accommodation: Hotel (Buenos Aires) >Included meals: breakfast >Private Bilingual guided tour included~ 4 h

Enjoy a free day. Our suggestions: SAN ANTONIO DE ARECO, a traditional gaucho town in the hearth of the Pampa. Learn about the lifestyle of the Gauchos in a traditional estancia. Taste a good piece of beef, the legendary asado Argentino and stroll on horseback or by horse buggy. EL TIGRE, a residential suburb located on the delta of the Parana River. It offers pleasant walks along the river and sailing tours. GUIDED TOUR CAN BE ARRANGED FOR YOU. Accommodation: Hotel (Buenos Aires) > Included meals: breakfast & dinner with Tango show

tourName: Highlights of Argentina tailor made tour
placesVisited: Buenos Aires, Tango show, El Calafate, Perito Moreno Glacier, El Chalten, Ushuaia, Tierra del Fuego National Park, Beagle Channel cruise, Puerto Iguazu, Iguazu Falls
generalInfo:
This tailor made tour of Argentina’s highlights gets started in buzzing Buenos Aires. A tour of the city’s historic and political districts will be top of the agenda, after which you’ll get the chance to experience the city’s legendary nightlife, with dinner and a tango show.

Argentina’s natural beauty is the main draw of this particular adventure, though, and soon you’ll be heading out into the wilderness. Highlights include visiting Los Glaciares National Park, where you’ll get up close to the Perito Moreno Glacier, and even walk on it, should you choose; trekking and canoeing through the stark beauty of Tierra del Fuego National Park; cruising the Beagle Channel in search of marine life; and marvelling at the thundering waters of Iguazu Falls.

dayInfo.description: Buenos Aires: Upon arrival you will be met at the airport and transferred by private service to your hotel, leaving you the remainder of the day to explore the historic neighborhoods and enjoy the cafe culture of Buenos Aires.

Buenos Aires Tour & Tango Show: Our City Tour will provide you a great overview of the city and its diverse attractions. Over the course of three hours you will have the chance to visit Retiro, Avenida 9 de Julio, Downtown, Puerto Madero, San Telmo, Recoleta and La Boca. In the evening you will be picked up from your hotel to be driven to a mystical place where you’ll discover one of our most ancient traditions. Tango is more than our national dance. Tango is: our immigrant origins, the talent of our local artists, the sensuality of the Argentine woman and our way to deal with a broken heart, dancing our way through tragical and yet eternal love stories. Tonight you will enjoy a 3 hour long professional display of tango and music with a group of local artists onstage immersed in an elegant and alluring place. The manners, ambience, clothes and dance steps which tango lovers used to practice 100 years ago will come to life again and you will travel in time for a night. This spectacular demonstration of the finest local dancing will be accompanied by delicious Argentine and international cuisine. Dinner is à la carte, beverages included so you can lose yourself in the ethereal taste of Malbec wine. At the end of the evening, around midnight, you will be driven back to your hotel, fully in love with the bohemian spirit of our beloved Buenos Aires. Duration: 3-4 hours Included: transportation mentioned above Note: formal dress is not required

Buenos Aires to El Calafate: At appropriate time you will be picked up at your hotel and transferred to the airport for your flight to El Calafate. Upon arrival you will be taken to the hotel and have the rest of the day to relax or explore the areas around the town or possible make the 1km hike out to Laguna Nimez for a beautiful Patagonian sunset.

Perito Moreno Glacier: Today you will enjoy a tour of Perito Moreno Glacier. Located in Los Glaciares National Park and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, Perito Moreno Glacier is one of the most awe inspiring destinations in Argentina. During your tour, you will have the chance to enjoy stunning views of the glacier's ice wall from the nearby walking & viewing trails. You will also be able to get up close to the glacier for some amazing photos on the included glacier cruise on Lake Argentino. Don't forget your camera! In the early evening you will be returned to you hotel. For even more adventure and the chance to actually go hiking on the glacier, ask about reserving the Big Ice excursion at the time of booking your trip. (Please note, the Big Ice excursion is not included in the tour price and due to limited availability needs to be reserved well in advance.)

El Calafate, Patagonia: Day at leisure to enjoy any of the optional tours around El Calafate. We suggest a visit to Estancia Cristina, a bike ride out to the lake, or a boat cruise to explore some of the more remote glaciers in the region.
El Calafate to El Chalten: At the appropriate time, you will be transferred from your hotel in Calafate to your hotel in El Chalten.

El Chalten, Patagonia: Day at leisure to enjoy one of many self guided treks. The trails are all well-marked and maintained. We recommend that you do the full-day hikes to Mount Fitz Roy (where the view of Laguna de los Tres is unforgettable) or Mount Torre. We will provide you with all the trekking information you may require.

El Chalten to El Calafate: Day at leisure to enjoy any of the self guided treks in the area. In the afternoon you will board your bus back to El Calafate. Upon arrival you will make your way from the bus station to your hotel. (In El Calafate a taxi will cost roughly $4 to get from the bus station to your hotel.)

El Calafate to Ushuaia, Patagonia: At appropriate time you will be transferred to the airport to take your flight to Ushuaia. Upon arrival, you will be transferred to your hotel leaving you the rest of the day to explore the city, try some delicious fresh seafood, or learn about the region's history at the Prisoners Museums.

Tierra del Fuego National Park, Ushuaia: After breakfast, you will leave on a full day excursion to Tierra del Fuego National Park that allows you to get off the tourist path and see a side of the park that most visitors miss. The excursion includes guided trekking and canoeing in this remote part of the southern hemisphere. (Box lunch is included).
Beagle Channel Navigation After making your way to the pier you will depart on the half day cruise of the Beagle Channel where you will enjoy some of the region’s most spectacular views.

Ushuaia to Puerto Iguazu: At appropriate time you will be taken to the airport to take your flight to Puerto Iguazu. Upon arrival, you will be taken to your hotel at which point you will have the afternoon to relax and enjoy the tropical climate and jungle setting.

Tour of Iguazu Falls- Argentine Side: After breakfast you will depart on a full day excursion to the Argentine side of the Iguazu Falls where you will have intimate views of this unforgettable section of the Iguazu River. Lower and upper walkways permit up close and personal experiences with this magnificent spectacle of nature. Trails through the 210 square mile reserve provide visitors with various views of the Falls, especially the largest one, Devil's Throat. The ecological train ride is included in the tour with an option to add the Safari Nautico boat trip taking you right up to the base of the Falls (this exiting excursion is highly recommended in order to feel the power of the Iguazu Falls. You should know that you will get 100% wet because it is like a “natural shower”. Be sure to take extra clothes if you want to do this extra excursion). Return to the hotel in the late afternoon.

Tour of Iguazu Falls- Brazilian Side / Iguazu to Buenos Aires After breakfast, enjoy a half day excursion to the Brazilian side of the Iguazu Falls where you will enjoy vast panoramic views of the Falls allowing you to take them in in their entirety. At appropriate time in the afternoon you will be transferred to the airport to take your flight to Buenos Aires. Upon arrival you will be taken to your hotel.
Buenos Aires: At appropriate time you will be escorted by private service to the international airport for your flight back home.

tourName: Horse riding and Mendoza wine tour in Argentina
generalInfo:
4 Days Special Private guided Wine, Hiking & Horseback riding offer in the Andes of Mendoza. All tailormade according to your tastes and style.

You have a full day private guided boutique wine tour with a 4x4 through Valle de Uco & visiting tourist attractions in the area in the same day, including exquisite lunch with wines. We head off towards Ruta 89 Las Carras, visit the highest located and oldest bodega of Mendoza, The Christ of Tupungato, a hand crafted knife factory KDS, a monastery plus wine tasting at any one of the these wineries : Kaiken, Sin Fin, Andesluna or Vistalba. And a visit to Salentein can be included as well of course. Lunch & wine included at boutique restaurant in the middle of the wine landscape with views on snow topped mountains .The wineries are family-owned and dedicated in producing high quality wines. tourName: Ibera Wetlands and Iguazu Falls holiday
generalInfo:
This trip is ideal for adventurers, nature lovers, and those curious about the local culture. On this trip, you will get to know one of the seven natural wonders: the Iguazu Falls, where the immensity of its waterfalls can be appreciated from both the Argentine and Brazilian sides of the National Park. You will also enjoy the pure nature of the wonderful Iberá Marshlands, the second-largest wetland in the world, famous for its diversity of fauna and vegetation.

The adventure begins in one of the 7 wonders of the world, with a tour of the Brazilian side of the falls where you can see the spectacular view of the Devil's Throat. You will also visit the Argentine side of the falls where you will take a navigation under the waterfalls (get ready for the water!!!). At the end of this adventure, enjoy a bike tour with our naturalist guide who will take you to the amazing trails of the jungle (Selva Misionera)

The trip continues in the great Iberá Marshlands. For 4 days, you will travel through this region famous for its biodiversity, abundant in alligators, deer of the marshes, capybaras, the renowned aguará-guazú, and countless species of native birds. You will hike to observe wildlife, horseback riding, boat trips, and night safari, among other activities.

dayInfo.description: In the morning you will take your flight to Puerto Iguazu. You will arrive at the quiet town of Puerto Iguazu. You can enjoy the rest of the day to: - Visit the animal refuge of Güra Oga, located 5 km away from the city center through de National Park road. This reserve is a veterinarian clinic and a rehabilitation center for injured wild animals. - Visit the hummingbird aviary: "El jardin de los picaflores". - Go to the point of view of the tripartite border of Argentina, Brazil and Paraguay. 1 km away to the west from Puerto IIguazú from, there is a craftwork market.

This day is dedicated to discovering the impressive Iguazú Falls, on the Argentinian side! In the morning, transfer to the famous Iguazu Falls. Once there, you're free to stroll along the footbridges to discover the impressive viewpoints. You will discover the 3 circuits: the Lower, the Upper and the famous Devil's Throat. Return to Puerto Iguazú Distance to cover on the footbridges Lower circuit: 1700 metres. Upper Circuit: 1750 metres. Garganta del Diablo route: first stage by train (ticket included). Second stage by footbridge: 2200 metres. Semiprivate tour with English-speaking guide. Entrance fees to the National Park are included. OPTION: you can take a boat trip to the foot of the falls.

Cycling in Iguazú National Park. This exclusive experience takes place in the Iguazu National Park. You will access it through a dirt road (RN 101 and the old entrance to the Iguazú Falls). It is located 15 kilometres from Puerto Iguazú, near the international airport and the entrance to Iguazú National Park. You will experience the wildest bike ride in the area and a unique experience of jungle exploration. Early in the morning there is a good chance of seeing birds, small mammals, butterflies and insects. It is also possible to discover different types of trees and plants. This is the territory of the largest predator in America, our "Criollo Tiger" called Yaguareté. Our guides have had the chance to see this incredible animal more than 25 times in the last 10 years. Pumas and other small predators share the same area. The tour starts at the police checkpoint (Gendarmería) on the national road 101, which connects Puerto Iguazú and the town of Comandante Andresito. This road is used by local farmers to transport their products, as well as by tourists who want to get to know the wilder part of the Park and the local people. From the police checkpoint, you will travel 2 kilometres to reach the entrance of a single track that turns left and ends in the Iguazú River. The guide will stop in different places to talk about the biodiversity of the jungle. Animal tracks are easy to see on the wet ground. The tour continues to an old campsite called Ñandu, where you can relax and enjoy the view of the river. Then it's time to return by taking the same road, travelling 5 kilometres to finish the tour. Difficulty: intermediate Kms. to ride: 10 km . Duration: 2hs by bike Departure between 6 and 7 AM

Today you will leave for the Iguazú National Park to discover the impressive views of the waterfalls from the Brazilian side (don't forget your passport!). Enjoy freely the different points of view from the numerous footbridges. After the visit, our guide will leave you at the Bird Park, where you will be able to explore the trails of the 5 large aviaries. In 4 of them, you can even get inside to admire the birds up close. A marked path allows you to discover the whole park in 2h. Return to Puerto Iguazú at the end of the evening. Tickets to Iguazu Falls and Bird Park included. Attention: starting from January 10, 2025, citizens of the United States, Canada, and Australia are required to obtain a visa to enter Brazil.

At 240 km from the city of Puerto Iguazú are the Jesuit Ruins of San Ignacio, Misiones. Known as San Ignacio Mini, it is the best preserved of the Jesuit missions in Argentine territory. The Ruins of San Ignacio date back to the 16th and 17th centuries, and despite the passage of time, most of the walls are still standing. In addition to access to the Jesuit missions, visitors can also enjoy a sound and light show. The journey from the city of Iguazú takes approximately 3 and a half hour (one way). A visit to the Wanda Mines is also included. Located 40 km from Puerto Iguazú and 260 km from Posadas, you will discover this deposit of semi-precious stones composed of quartz crystals, amethysts, agates, and topazes, among the most important. Situated on the mighty Paraná River, visitors can enjoy this unique outdoor attraction. Entrances included Private excursion, English-speaking guide

You will meet your guide and take a 4x4 vehicle transfer from Posadas to the Estancia. This can take between 5 and 7 hours depending on weather conditions, as it is a gravel road. Upon arrival, you will be welcomed by local hosts who will provide you with more detailed information about The Conservation Land Trust, which was founded in 2001 by conservation philanthropist Douglas Tompkins. The goal of this organization was to create a natural reserve of 74,130 acres. With the acquisition of Socorro and other areas within Iberá, CLT's objectives were simple and ambitious: to create the largest natural park in Argentina, restore species that had disappeared from the region, and promote an economy based on ecotourism. They launched the most extensive rewilding program in the Americas: giant anteaters, pampas deer, tapirs, and collared peccaries have been reintroduced. Rincón del Socorro is located within the Iberá National Park, where one can observe a variety of natural ecosystems: vast grasslands temporarily flooded known as marshlands, beautiful Caranday palm trees, red grasslands, savannas, thorny hills, and gallery forests. Lunch will be prepared with organic vegetables from the garden, and you will taste typical recipes from the province of Corrientes as well as Argentine and international dishes. For the rest of the day, depending on the schedule, you can participate in available activities. Dinner included.

Many activities can be done at Rincón del Socorro, but the schedule is based on weather and climatic conditions. Upon arrival, the guide will explain the schedules and options for the next day. On foot, you will have the possibility of concentrating on looking for tracks detecting the presence of recently reintroduced animals. While walking there will be time to look for the best angle for a photo, to dwell on the details, and to know more about the species around. Over the past years in Rincon del Socorro, Reserve Giant Anteaters, Collared Peccaries, and Pampas Deers have been reintroduced with success. Alternatively, in outings on horse, you will have a different point of view that will allow for an enjoyment of the landscape heightened by the contact with the animal, which will easily sort through streams and pastures, and will also favor the sighting of different types of Deers, among other creatures. On a horse, one can reach the coast of the marshlands and ride along it. The boat trips are done in the area of Laguna Iberá (lagoon) and Colonia Carlos Pellegrini. The village has an interpretation center and very nice trails along the lagoon and through the native forest. The economy of this town was transformed in 1983 when the Provincial Park was created. Before then the inhabitants used to hunt for a living. Today Pellegrini is a proud town that learned how to conserve and care for its natural heritage and make it a way of living. The boat trips allow you to get close to Alligators, Capybaras, and hundreds of birds without scaring them. The tours take around 2 hours and are frequently done over the Iberá Lagoon and sometimes we can also kayak through the floating islands or embalsados. Horseback rides, walks, and boat trips might be combined with night safaris that make possible magnificent encounters with very active wildlife that take advantage of the cool nights to go hunting. If the sky is clear, night sky watching might also take place. This activity sometimes is also accompanied by a spectacular nature show: thousands of fireflies decorating the surroundings. It seems like they are trying to copy the Milky Way. Many of the roads can also be cycled on mountain bikes. Rincón del Socorro sets itself as an excellent location for bird watching, where the visitor has the possibility of observing native species like the Yellow Cardinal (Gubernatrix cristata), and the Strange-Tailed Tyrant (Alectrurus risora), among others. In total, the complete list of birds in the region reaches 350 species. Many of the activities can be accompanied by picnics, food always tastes better in nature. These stops present a good opportunity to recover energy and to observe every detail that nature has to offer. It is worthwhile also taking the time to visit Uguay, the nearest village, to learn about the culture of the inhabitants of the wetlands, its crafts and its way of life. There the visitant can try a “mate correntino” (local beverage) perhaps for the first time, accompanied by some “torta fritas” (a traditional fried bread) and great stories of the hosts. At the lodge, you will have the possibility of enjoying the different areas of the house by relaxing by the pool, being captivated by the books in the library, or participating in talks and videos that will allow the visitor to gain deeper knowledge in the projects carried out by Fundación Rewilding Argentina. The ample gardens are constantly visited by the local fauna and can be easily walked in order to reach a nearby small wetland where one can observe and appreciate the native animals. In addition, the vegetable garden provides another beautiful attraction through its sustainable growth and its production of vegetables that reach everyday meals. Being a guest in Rincón del Socorro is a way of being a part of the ambitious project that CLT has proposed and carried through with undeniable success.

tourName: Killer whale watching tour in Argentina
generalInfo:
See one of the world's most spectacular natural events. Come to Patagonia in time to see the resident Orca hunting seal pups by torpedoing onto the beaches before thrashing their way back off with their prey in caught.

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including three meals per day (breakfast, lunch and dinner). There will be bottled water (approx 1ltr) available for each guest each day. We have our own private air conditioned 4x4 vehicles for all transfers. We include a professional zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) to escort you on all your excursions and also a very knowledgeable English speaking local guide. Your zoologist escort (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) is an expert in cetacean (whale and dolphin) biology and behaviour and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. For example the subtle learning techniques that the orcas use to teach the younger whales the hunt and individual differences in each orca so you begin to get to know individuals. One of the joys of having a zoologist escort (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) is that you will not miss any sightings. We also use excellent local whale watching naturalists, with years of experience in observing the orcas as well as other whales and dolphins of the area. Also included are all boat trips, wildlife viewing and park fees are included as well as access to the private estancia where the hunting beach is located in Punta Norte. If you want access to the ‘Attack Channel’, (this is unprecedented access to the hunting zone where the BBC film crew shot the stunning scenes for the series The Trails of Life) you will have to pay the government imposed permit fee, which is discussable on booking as the price fluctuates. A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on blue whales which are available to watch throughout the tour.

Seasons:

The exact season varies a little but from late February to early April is usually the entire season for this tour. During a 5-6 week period from late February to early April the transient pod of orcas start to hunt the southern sea lion and southern elephant seal pups as they take the water for the first time. The exact time of this unique behaviour varies and is dependant on fish stocks which speed up or slow down the seal development and therefore when they take to the surf for the first time. Over the last couple of decades the vast majority of attacks have been recorded in March and this is when the hunting usually reaches a peak.

Introduction:

There are no other UK based tour operators that offer a tour specifically to view this unique and stunning hunting behaviour. Ever since the 1993 BBC Natural History series ‘The Trails of Life’ aired footage of magnificent orcas launching themselves onto the beaches of Patagonia in an attempt to catch the young seal and sea lion pups; this wildlife spectacle has become one of the top destinations on most whale watchers and wildlife photographers wish lists. However arranging all the necessary permits, paying the government and national park fees and just finding access to the correct hunting beach can be very hard to organise and understand. Which is why we decided to simplify things and offer the chance to see the only beaching orcas in the world hunting without any of the hassle of having to organise the permits yourself. In addition to this we have broken down the type of viewing available for this tour into three easy to understand and different options. The reason for this being that Patagonia in general and this tour particularly can be very expensive so depending on your budget we can tailor this tour for you. Below are the 3 different budget options for this tour.

1. The cheapest option is to use public viewing area on the edge of Peninsula Valdes, this is where the vast majority of tourists coming to see the orcas base themselves and the distance to the hunting beaches is around 200-300m. We recommend this for people who are interested in other wildlife as well as the orcas, as we can spend more time searching for guanacos, armadillos, foxes, seals, dolphins and penguins around Peninsula Valdes. Also if you are interested in exploring more of Patagonia we recommend this option.

2. The mid range option (which is included in the below itinerary) differs from option 1 in staying on the hunting beach itself. The beach where the seals and sea lions pup and the orcas hunt is the private property of a local estancia (ranch). This is a very small boutique ranch (6 rooms) and we have an arrangement with the owners. This is where the BBC (and all other documentary makers) based themselves to film the spectacle. The ranch owners and knowledgeable staff understand the behaviour of the orcas here better than anyone and will help you by setting up hides on the beach and even taking you out on boats to where the orcas launch their attacks, you will be in the best place for a beaching attack.

3. The final option is only recommended for dedicated wildlife watchers and professional photographers. This is due to the heavy permit fees involved with gaining access to the ‘Attack Channel’. You will use the same estancia as described in option 2 but with special permission from the Argentine government you will be taken to less than 50m or so of the ‘Attack Channel’. The ‘Attack Channel’ is where the orcas usually perform all their hunting. It is the location where all of exceptional shots and footage of the hunting orcas are taken from. This is a real heart pounding experience and can only be done with the an overseer employed by the government and only a handful of permits are granted each year, but you will be standing only a few meters away from the surf zone and you will never forget the sight of a 10 ton orca rushing out of the waves in front of you to pluck a seal pup from the beach.

We ask anyone interested in this tour to please let us know what budget you have for this tour and if you have any specific ideas on which option you would like to book. We specialise in tailoring wildlife watching tours all over the world to suit all people’s requirements and budgets and are confident that whatever your budget for this tour we can arrange your ideal Patagonian wildlife experience.

Why Choose this Tour:

• We offer three different options for this tour (detailed above), depending on your budget and particular interests.
• You have the chance to stay in the one and only estancia which owns the land where the orcas hunt and have exceptional access to the seal and sea lion colony for close up shots.
• We can arrange use of a boat to go out to where the orcas patrol, this is an exciting and new way of observing the hunting orcas before and during their unique hunting.
• If requested we can bring equipment such as a hydrophone (to hear the orcas under the water) and also an underwater camera which will attempt to film the whales and dolphins underneath the waves.
• This tour is like none other being offered by a UK based operator, you will not only get access to the best locations to watch the hunting orcas but we can also arrange further wildlife watching throughout Patagonia as well as taking in some of the most spectacular landscapes in the world.
• We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides all over Argentina that are able to find and observe animals like Commerson’s dolphins, southern fur seals, Magenellic penguins, culpeo foxes, giant anteaters, greater rheas, pumas, fairy armadillos, southern elephant seals, coypus, jaguarundis and hundreds other endangered, rare or endemic species throughout this wilderness land. Whether it is Los Glaciares, Tierra del Fuego, Chaco, Iguazu, Campo de los Alisos, El Palmar and many other wildlife watching locations you want to visit we can arrange it. Please inform us if you wish to add a Argentina extensions to this orca watching itinerary below and we can provide an excellent wildlife watching itinerary and quote for you.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

The only place in the world where this orca hunting style exists in the world is off one or two beaches along the Peninsula Valdes in Patagonia, Argentina. Making Punta Norte just about the most exciting whale watching destination in the world. We recommend at least 3 full days here (the longer the better) and can also arrange tours to all other areas of Patagonia and Argentina in general.

Fitness Level:

There is no real fitness level required for our orca watching holidays to Patagonia, you decide on the amount of walking involved in the tour.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; but as a rule of thumb we recommend that you bring your own binoculars or spotting scope as well as suitable clothing which would be a mix of cool, light clothing as well as warm winter clothes as the weather can be unpredictable and long hours on exposed beaches can get windy. Water proofs and a wind-breaker are also recommended. Comfortable walking shoes are a must, just in case you decide to head out for a hike in search of armadillos or guanacos. A sunhat and sun cream are also recommended. Of course plenty of film or memory cards for your camera as well as any other items of a personal nature which you will require whilst away.

Minimum Age: 12 Years old.

dayInfo.description: Peninsula Valdes – Arrival – On arrival at Buenos Aires airport you will be met by your local driver/guide transferred to the domestic airport in time to catch our onward flight to the Patagonian town of Trelew. On arrival here you will be met by our local guide who will take you in our private00204x4 vehicles to Peninsula Valdes. When you arrive in the coastal village of Puerto Piramides you will be shown to your accommodation. Before enjoying a welcome to Argentina meal and preparing for tomorrows whale watching. (Lunch and or Dinner included (depending on the time of arrival)).

Peninsula Valdes – Whale Watching– Today will be your first taste of whale watching here as you have an early morning boat trip. As well as the orca which will probably be on a morning patrol there are up to 10 other species of marine mammal you can see here. There are no fewer than 5 species of dolphin to spot, not including the largest dolphin of them all the orca. There is also the chance of seeing southern right whales here (even though they are not calving at this time of year they are still here in reasonable numbers). Then there is the orcas prey, the southern sea lions, southern elephant seals, Magellanic penguins occupy the beaches in large number and always make for interesting watching. After lunch you will have the rest of the day to explore the terrestrial side of the Peninsula. But do not despair as the land is also rich in wildlife, hairy armadillos, guanacos, foxes and various caracaras all live around here, so the wildlife watching is defiantly not confined to the sea. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included)

Punta Norte – Orca Watching – The next three days will be spent at the exclusive estancia where the orcas beach themselves in pursuit of the seal and sea lion pups. Depending on what you are after we can tailor these three days to your perfect requirements. If you would like we can set up hides on the beach for you to stake out the orcas and wait for the famous attacks, we can see about getting a boat out onto the water to be in and amongst the orcas as they launch their attacks and see the beach and the seal colonies from the orca’s point of view. This is not always available, as the weather, tides and general behaviour of the orcas has to be taken into account as all these factors can lead to going out in a small boat being far too dangerous. Another option would be to just walk amongst the seals and sea lions and watch the patrolling orcas and hope that you catch an attack. We can also arrange for you to visit the Megallanic penguin colony at Punta Tombo (an hour or so drive north), the penguin colony is at its peak in February but there are often a few penguins still around in March. But probably the most exciting option is to access the ‘Attack Channel’, this can only be arranged well in advance and has a heavy price tag (usually around US$750-1000 per person per day), but this price does fluctuate and is worth it, when you catch the photos of orcas rushing into shore in front of you. There are also plenty of land based activities and wildlife watching as well and you will have the use of the 4x4 jeeps (with a driver) to explore the ranch and try to spot some of the unusual wildlife here. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included)

Los Glaciares National Park – Wildlife Watching – After breakfast you will be transferred from Punta Notre and Peninsula Valdes to Trelew to catch the internal flight further south in Patagonia and to the Andes. Our destination is Calafate. Calafate is one of the most beautiful places in Patagonia and the accommodation here is perched on the hillside, with incredible views of the glacial lake. The rest of the day is free for you to relax and take in the incredible landscape. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included)

Los Glaciares National Park – Glacier Trip - After an early breakfast you will be transferred to a catamaran at 7:00am. The catamaran will take you around some of the most impressive glaciers in the world, including Upsala the largest glacier in South America and without a shadow of a doubt, one of the most stunning. Seeing these impressive glaciers from water level is a truly unforgettable experience and there is the chance of finding some interesting and endemic animals here such as Andean condors, Humboldt’s hog-nosed skunk, gray foxes, Andean ruddy duck, Magellanic woodpeckers and Austral parakeets to name a few. As part of the trip you will opportunity to walk through the pristine nothofagus forests to see the glaciers up close. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included)

Los Glaciares National Park. Wildlife Watching – Today is your last full day in Argentina and you will the morning visiting a small nature reserve located in marshland. This is a great birding area is home to Chilean flamingos, five species of raptor as well as numerous mammals such as puma if you are very lucky. After a packed lunch you will leave the marshland and travel to some Patagonian bluffs where you will have a chance of spotting Andean condors on their roosting sites as well as visiting the famous Perito Moreno glacier. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

Home – Departure - After an early breakfast you will be transferred to the local airport in time to catch your return flight to Buenos Aires and of course your return flight home. (Breakfast and Lunch only)

tourName: Luxury Argentina holiday, tailormade
generalInfo:
In two weeks, discover Argentina’s most revered places without compromising on comfort. From vibrant city life to ancient forests, glacier-fed lakes and world-class wines, you’ll experience it all whilst escaping the crowds and staying at South America’s most spectacular hotels and lodges.

Begin in Buenos Aires, immersing yourself in Argentina’s culinary scene and the rhythms of tango. Fly south to Patagonia, where surreal landscapes amaze at every turn. Continue north to Argentina’s renowned winelands with a stay at boutique winery, where time is spent exploring the vineyards, attending tastings, wandering the Andean foothills or simply relaxing on the estate grounds. End your stay in the Sierras Chicas of Cordoba for an authentic experience of Argentine gaucho culture.

Every detail of this experience has been seamlessly curated, with excursions, transfers and gourmet meals to show you an authentic and luxury journey through Argentina. This trip can be tailored to your interests, so let us know your preferences.

dayInfo.description: Buenos Aires: Welcome to the Buenos Aires. Upon arrival, settle into your luxury hotel in cosmopolitan Puerto Madero. Over the next few days, let your expert local guide show you the city highlights and history on a walking tour and indulge on a culinary journey through Argentine gastronomy at a traditional Asado experience.

El Calafate: Fly south to Patagonia and journey to an exclusive lodge, nestled in a stunning natural setting. Hidden from the crowds, this gem offers a multitude of outdoor activities where you can hike, bike or horse-ride several unexplored trails. During your stay, visit Los Glaciares National Park with a guide and admire the Perito Moreno Glacier. Strap on your crampons and hike across the glacier itself for a unique and close-up perspective of one of the world’s most impressive glaciers.

Winelands: Continue to Mendoza, the heart of Argentina’s winelands and home of the Malbec. Stay at a luxury boutique winery nestled in the foothills of the Andes. During your stay, savour private wine tastings and vineyard tours, experience a cooking class with a signature chef and dine on the regions fresh and seasonal ingredients, all while soaking up the mountain views and temperate weather. For adventure, venture to the Andes on horseback or foot or cycle between vineyards.

Cordoba: Fly north to Cordoba, for a contrasting landscape and experience. Stay on a traditional family ranch, where you are welcomed to experience the best horse-riding and gaucho culture. Explore trails through pastures, spot a variety of bird species, hike to secluded waterfalls and indulge in home-cooked family meals and discover the endangered traditions and culture of Argentina’s rural communities.

Buenos Aires: Say goodbye to Cordoba and fly south to Buenos Aires, where you’ll spend one final night before heading home. For your final night, with your guide, head to an underground milonga where you can experience an authentic Tango and discover the heartbeat of Buenos Aires.

tourName: Mendoza wine tour in Argentina
generalInfo: This 3 day Mendoza Wine Tour features the vineyards of Mendoza and includes guided visits to the traditional wineries to sample the rich Malbec and Cabernet. Located at the base of the Andes Mountains and nearby Mount Aconcagua, Mendoza is known for its year-round sunshine, gourmet restaurants and delicious wines. With boutique hotels as well as comfortable budget accommodation available, the Mendoza Wine Tour offers something for everyone.

dayInfo.description: Mendoza: Argentina's main wine region and heartland of Malbec grape, has also impressive mountains (like Aconcagua, climbers world known summit), outdoor sports (adventurous rafting) and breathtaking landscapes. Upon arrival, you will be taken to your hotel. Private Service.

Full-Day Wineries Tour: In the morning, we will pick you up to explore Argentina’s famous Wine Road and visit some of the regions most highly acclaimed wineries. Accompanied by expert guides we learn about the production facilities, the different styles of wine-making, the gastronomy and we will have a great wine tasting. You will visit Maipu or Lujan de Cuyo depending on the operativity of the wineries. Maipu is the first viticultural area in Argentina. It was the location chosen by the first European immigrants to continue their most beloved family tradition; wine-making. Here the residents found the perfect climate and soil conditions to maintain their passion, eventually gaining international recognition for the excellence of their wines. In this region, olive-groves and vineyards sit side-by-side, making it the perfect place to enjoy an Argentine wine and olive-oil experience. Lujan de Cuyo, the region known as The Cradle of Malbec. Surrounded by gentle hills and over-looked By America’s highest mountains, Lujan de Cuyo is known for its country houses, tree-lined streets, fine restaurants, Malbec vineyards, olives and world-renowned wineries. This quaint, picturesque town is the perfect place to enjoy a captivating wine experience. In the area, we visit some of the regions most prestigious wineries where we will have guided tours and the opportunity to learn about the production facilities, the different styles of wine-making, the gastronomy and we will have a great wine tasting. We will enjoy a winery lunch prepared by a renowned chef, who has developed the best gourmet dishes to accompany the various varietals of wine produced here. After lunch, we will take you back to your hotel, with a clear picture of the diversity involved in the world of wine, the gastronomy and Mendoza’s landscape. Type of service: Semiprivate Duration: 8/9 hours Included: Transportation mentioned above, bilingual guide (English / Spanish), lunch in a winery, visit to 3 different wineries Age restriction: Wine tasting only for people older than 18 years Note: Have a good breakfast before starting the tour to enjoy the tastings. The visits in the wineries are not private (other people may be at the winery at the same time). Wineries may change according to season. They will be confirmed when booking.

Mendoza: At appropriate time, you will have a private transfer to the airport or bus terminal. Today, you can choose to extend your travels purchasing any of our available offers in Buenos Aires, Iguazu Falls or the Andes area.

tourName: North East Argentina holiday
placesVisited: Buenos Aires, Mercedes, Ibera’s Wetlands, Camba Trapo Estuary, Posadas, Estancia Las Marias, Santo Pipo, Tea and mate plantations, Visit traditional Guarani villages, Guarani homestay, San Ignacio Mini, Rainforest hikes, Iguazu Falls, Mocona Falls
generalInfo:
This Argentina holiday is a journey around some of the natural heritage highlights in the north west of the country, travelling on a tailor made itinerary for nearly two weeks. During this trip you will get a chance to explore some of the country’s most stunning landscapes which vary from the rich jungles which are home to the indigenous Guarani people, to the great waterfalls of Iguazu and Mocona.

Wildlife enthusiasts will love northern Argentina, especially the rainforest regions which are home to the most exquisite birdlife and flora. As well as monkeys and caimans, some of which you will discover on guided hikes around the rainforests. The lagoons of Ibera, one of South America’s largest wetlands, are home to more than 400 species, as well as a vast array of plants, which we will discover on a boat trip across the lagoons. A highlight for many of our guests is a rainforest hike led by Guarani guides, as well as homestay within their indigenous and traditional community.

Back on the tourist trail, but worth every bit of the journey, is Iguazu Falls, a national park that is home to one of the greatest cascades on earth right up on the border with Brazil. This natural wonder is actually a collection of 275 waterfalls ranging between 40 and 80m in drop and spread over a distance of 2.5km.

On this holiday, although independent by nature, you will be given 24 hour mobile phone support and use a mixture of private and public transfers. We provide a detailed travel itinerary and handbook with all the information you need to find the sites above, as well as your carefully chosen accommodation.

dayInfo.description: After landing in Buenos Aires, our driver will take you to your hotel, located in the city centre. A member of our team will provide you with a road book and a mobile phone to be in contact with us 24/7. He/she will accompany around the city, to the most famous and picturesque areas: El Caminito and San Telmo, at the origins of Tango, then the ancient harbour, heart of the city.
