dayInfo.description: In the morning, you will stoke the coals and sizzling embers from last night's fire to help your new friends prepare a stunning breakfast to be enjoyed amongst Patagonia’s flawless wilderness backdrop. Today, you will relish the unique opportunity to assist the Gauchos herd their cattle, an inspiring experience sharing insight into these local folks' rural way of life. Exploring the tricks of their trade and delving into the history and myths shrouding this bucolic landscape and the people dwelling here, you will find solace in the exceptional stories shared within Patagonia’s unspoiled paradise.

dayInfo.title: Chubut - On the Banks of Lago Puelo
dayInfo.description: You will spend your final morning on horseback slowly trotting from camp, down the country roads, towards an old rural school hemmed into the peaceful pastures. Before reaching the Old School meeting point, you will bid farewell to your Gaucho guides and enjoy the last stretch of travel on foot. You will relish this time taking in your surroundings and capturing the wilderness up close before meeting your private transfer who will whisk you away to Lago Puelo. Your evening, spent at a delightful accommodation near the banks of the glistening lake, will be a relaxing end to the day.

dayInfo.title: Chubut - Delicious Delicacies Cooked on the Open Flame
dayInfo.description: Today marks your final full day in Argentina, as you make your way closer to the Chilean border on foot during a splendid hike from your bed and breakfast to your next campsite. The leisurely stroll will lead you across the shimmering shores of Lake Puelo, where you may snap up pictures of the sun-washed waters and spot creatures rustling through the overgrown shrubbery. You will arrive at a campsite just shy of the Chilean border, where you will cook bubbling pots over the roaring fire as the stars light up the night sky.

dayInfo.title: Llanquihue - First Steps on Chilean Soil
dayInfo.description: Your hike will bring you to the Chilean border sometime this morning, where you will proceed through customs and take your first steps on Chilean soil. Upon crossing the border, you will board a motor-boat and speed across the shiny sapphire surface of Las Rocas Lake to a stunning accommodation tucked away in the viridian forests veiling the small, wildlife sanctuary of Las Bandurrias island. Scenes of the crystal clear water circling your charming accommodation and sounds of the endemic creatures whistling from the untouched canopy will introduce you to the beauty of Chile’s preserved ecosystems.

dayInfo.title: Llanquihue - Admire the Astonishing Azul Lake
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you will set out to visit the still, crystal clear waters of Azul Lake, a diverse destination teeming with fish life and fragrant flora all blooming beneath the mighty snow-capped peaks of the magnificent mountains. Your trek will lead you through forests along shaded paths to the ancient Alerce and Arrayan trees growing mightily tall within the Valdivian-type rainforest. You will spend a few moments tucking into a picnic lunch on the shores of the lake before returning to your resort and lapping up the luxuries of your spellbinding surroundings.

dayInfo.title: Llanquihue - Lookouts Looming over Las Rocas Lake
dayInfo.description: A short motor-boat crossing this morning will take you from your accommodation to the golden shores of Playa Mosquito beach. From here, you will begin your ascent of the hill bordering Las Rocas Lake, walking through fields of lush vegetation and up slopes carpeted in giant trees. Lookouts peppering the precipice will afford marvelous vistas of the surrounding landscape while rest stops in the forest will give you a chance to admire the colossal ancient trees sprouting between the greenery. Your adventures today will come to an enchanting conclusion as you return to the surface and luxuriate in the lake.

dayInfo.title: Puerto Varas - Touring the Towns of Chile
dayInfo.description: Savor a mouth-watering homemade breakfast before cruising across the lake to a meeting point where you will join your driver. From here, you will begin your transfer to a series of fascinating Chilean towns speckling the region, first arriving at Llanada Grande and crossing Tagua Tagua Lake to relish lunch in Río Puelo. Continuing along a road winding with the lake’s shores, you will soon reach Cochamó, a town drenched in ancient culture and insightful heritage highlights. Your tour will conclude in Puerto Varas, where you will check into a spectacular, architectural masterpiece boasting unrivaled views of Osorno Volcano.

dayInfo.title: Puerto Varas - Saying Goodbye to South America
dayInfo.description: You may appreciate the Chilean sunrise from your terrace as the wilderness comes alive around you with creatures leaping from the trees and birds releasing melodic cries. After breakfast, you will be collected by your driver and taken to the airport where you will board your plane bound for home. You will bid your farewells to South America, a destination rich in wilderness beauty that will have been your home to cherish during your adventurous travels through Patagonia. You will look back on this trip with fondness for the authentic experiences enjoyed in both Argentina and Chile.

tourName: Cultural Kaleidoscope Road Trip from Salta to the Atacama
placesVisited: Salta, Cachi, Molinos, Cafayate, Tilcara, Atacama Desert
generalInfo: Argentina and Chile boast picturesque Patagonian forests and remarkable cultural destinations peppering this unspoiled paradise, all of which you may admire on this immersive 12-day road trip sharing the heritage of these South American countries and their people with you. Traveling from the bustling city of Salta to the immense Salt Flats of Atacama Desert, you will explore the kaleidoscopic culture of Patagonia.

dayInfo.title: Salta - A Skyline Shrouded in Spanish Colonial Culture
dayInfo.description: Boasting rich Spanish colonial culture and a skyline that matches its historic, 1582 origins, the northwestern Argentinian city of Salta will take you on a dreamy trip back in time from the minute you step off the airplane and transfer to your accommodation hemmed into the heart of the cityscape. You may spend your afternoon exploring its districts, strolling past the iconic dark red walls of the San Francisco Church to a chairlift ascending to the peaks of San Bernado. Marvel at the alluring views before meandering down the woodland paths to the famous monument of General 'Gaucho' G�üemes.

dayInfo.title: Cachi - Alluring Visions of the Argentinian Landscape
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, you will check out of your accommodation and climb into your rental vehicle to begin your ascent up the emerald hills of the Lerma Valley, along the forest-flanked roads weaving through the Yungas, and across the cacti-covered unending expanse of Los Cardones National Park. Your adventures will lead you to the charming city of Cachi, where you will find refuge beneath the shady trees circling the courtyard and whitewashed buildings of your quirky Andean resort. You will spend your afternoon lapping up the scenic luxuries and relaxing in this far-flung destination.

dayInfo.title: Molinos - Riveting Red Sandstone Walls of the Acsibi Caves
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will continue your journey across the flourishing fields of Calchaqui Valley, galavanting along Artisan’s Road, so named for its flurry of textiles and ponchos draped from the windows of modest little homes. Arriving at the sleepy mountain town of Seclantas, you will meet a cheerful local and be whisked away in his Jeep deeper into the wilds for a canyon hike like no other. You will stroll along the dry riverbed until the canyon becomes a cave, encouraging you to crawl through its narrow aperture to reach the mesmerizing red sandstone walls of the Acsibi Caves beyond.

dayInfo.title: Cafayate - The Culture of the Diaguita Indigenous Community
dayInfo.description: The morning sun will warm your hacienda, inviting you to step outside and soak up its vitalizing golden embrace before you continue along the canyon-fringed roads weaving through Las Flechas Valley. Your travels will give you the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to live like a local as you are welcomed by residents of the Diaguita indigenous community at Corralito. Guided tours of their bountiful plantations, walks between the cascading vineyards veiling their lands, and lunch enjoyed from farm-to-table will bring you closer to the local community and Argentina’s diverse culture. Afterward, you will make tracks for the gorgeous wine region of Cafayate.

dayInfo.title: Cafayate - Sipping Fine Vintages in the North West Wine Capital
dayInfo.description: Argentina’s North West wine capital, Cafayate, is the oldest wine-producing region in the country and it is home to a collection of spectacular wine estates. It was in this very vineyard-coated paradise that the Spanish Conquistadors and Jesuits came bearing the seeds that would produce Argentina’s first vintages. Today, the estate vineyards compose the stunning scenery and their meticulous processes produce an array of delectable wines you will have the pleasure of sipping on as you tuck into an assortment of sumptuous snacks from a terrace overlooking the unspoiled countryside.

dayInfo.title: Tilcara - Magic in the Heart of the Humahuaca Valley
dayInfo.description: From Cafayate, you will begin your adventures north where viridian vineyards unrolling across the hilly landscape will give way to deep red rocks composing the jagged walls of Las Conchas Gorge. Passing by the ancient rock formations, you will soon find yourself descending the familiar verdant Lerma Valley where you will drop off your rental vehicle in Salta. Collected by a driver and guide, your tour will continue up the proliferating hills and down to the heart of the Humahuaca Valley, where you will admire the region's colorful culture from within the magical little town of Tilcara.

dayInfo.title: Tilcara - To Lofty Viewpoints alongside Llamas
dayInfo.description: For centuries, people residing in the Andes have relied on llamas as transportation across the difficult terrain of rugged mountains and vast plateaus. The llama has been a coveted creature in Andean culture and, today, you will walk alongside them in the Humahuaca Valley to lofty viewpoints sharing marvelous spectacles of the sandy surrounding region where you will tuck into a delightful traditional picnic lunch. Your trusted navigator will share stories of the land on which you walk and recount fables of the ancient people who once rode llamas along these parts in the same way.

dayInfo.title: Atacama Desert - Travels across the Chilean Border
dayInfo.description: You will leave Tilcara this morning and make your way up to the expansive plateau of La Puna, where you will gaze across Argentina’s largest salt flats before arriving at the Chilean border. Crossing into Chile, you will reach a gorgeous accommodation pinned in the velvety sands of the breathtaking Atacama Desert. With its distinct blend of modern and traditional architecture, the terracotta-colored resort will be a welcomed refuge within this beautifully desolate region. You may spend your first evening wallowing in your accommodation’s amenities before turning in for the night and sleeping beneath the starry sky.

dayInfo.title: Atacama Desert - A Geothermal Wonderland
dayInfo.description: From bubbling geysers to salty basins, the Atacama Desert is a geological wonderland you will be thrilled to explore during your stay. Today, you may set off on your own or be joined by a tour guide to take in all the untouched beauty spreading across Atacama’s vast sandy landscape. Along the way, you may stumble upon a flamboyance of flamingos cooling off in all their dazzling pink allure within the shallow lakes pouring across the sand. In the background, mighty snow-capped mountains will rise to touch the clouds and the golden desert will unfold towards the horizon.

dayInfo.title: Atacama Desert - Jaw-dropping Encounters with the Geysers of Tatio
dayInfo.description: Several marvelous sightings and adventures await in Atacama, with today’s travels of choice bringing you to the steamy Geysers of Tatio. Before the sun has risen while the stars still twinkle in the night sky, you will zigzag around the Andes Mountains to the piping hot natural springs. Thick clouds of steam billow from the springs and rise above the hard sandstone floors on which you will walk, creating a vision worth capturing in all its natural splendor. Your guide will share more information about these geothermal landscapes and the remarkable activity brewing underground.

dayInfo.title: Atacama Desert - Soaring Scenes atop Aguas Calientes
dayInfo.description: You will have scraped the surface of what Atacama has to offer by the time your final full day in Chile arrives, and you will spend it exploring more of the phenomenal region. Today’s adventures will bring you to the enchanting white landscape of Capur’s Salt Flats. You will hike the face of a towering mountain fringing the flats, wandering across sandy pathways to lookout points offering panoramic vistas of the multi-colored topography. From a striking vantage point atop the Aguas Calientes, you will be rewarded with unforgettable scenes of Atacama’s undulating lands.

dayInfo.title: Atacama Desert - Golden Desert Mornings and Goodbyes
dayInfo.description: The sun will rise over the sandy dunes and sandstone mountains circling your stunning accommodation, flooding the Atacama Desert with golden light that shimmers off its soft landscape. You will soak up these scenes one last time as you slowly pack your bags and head down for breakfast, all while reminiscing about the remarkable cultural adventures enjoyed throughout this South American tour. After breakfast, you will meet your private transfer in the lobby and be whisked away to the airport where you will take to the skies on board your flight heading home.

tourName: Embracing the Vine: The Ultimate Argentina Wine Tour
placesVisited: Buenos Aires, Mendoza, Salta, Jujuy, Humahuaca Gorge, Valley of Las Conchas River, Cerro de la Gloria, Cafayate
generalInfo: The fruit of the vine becomes a gateway to culture during your handcrafted Argentina wine tour. Let the vines lead you through a history of the country as seen by both Spanish conquistadors and indigenous peoples. Explore the trails shaped by European immigrants crafting new ventures into wine production in a new world. Embrace the rugged terrain of the Humahuaca Gorge and sample the most memorable varietals in the most unexpected places, such as in the staggering altitudes of the Andean foothills, exploring how Argentina has taken the world by storm as a celebrated producer of fantastic wines. For additional Argentina travel destinations, browse our other Argentina wine tours on Zicasso.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Arrive in Gorgeous Buenos Aires with an Introductory Tour
dayInfo.description: The city of Buenos Aires has an elegant ambiance emanating from the blend of South American spirit and European architecture reminiscent of the tree-lined streets of Paris. The 19th-century facades intersperse high-rise luxury apartments. Also, like Paris, each of the 47 “barrios” of Buenos Aires has a distinct character separate from the rest of the city like an enclave devoted to bohemian art, antiques, or certain cuisine. Your flight arrives at Ministro Pistarini International Airport, where your private transfer greets you upon arrival. The aroma of rich coffee emanates from the cafes fading beneath the buttery scent of pastry dough emanating from the bakeries making savory empanadas. You take some time to settle into the comforts of your elegant hotel in the Recoleta. The barrio has established itself as the center of culture with broad, shady avenues, fashionable boutiques, and an undeniable European ambiance. Your guide meets you at the hotel and escorts you on an introductory tour of Buenos Aires leading you to the city’s civic heart at the Plaza de Mayo. The president’s mansion, known as the Casa Rosada crowns the plaza with 19th-century architectural design and an unforgettable pink hue. The structure was erected over the foundations of the 16th-century Spanish fortress. A museum opened in 1957 displays presidential memorabilia such as sashes, batons, and furniture, as well as excavations of the original fortress. The mansion brings the prestige of the city to the forefront, as well as the history of Argentina from the Spanish Rule to Independence as the long avenues connect with the shopping district of Avenida Florida.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Visit a Wine Tasting Club before a Dining Experience
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the streets of the La Boca neighborhood shine with multi-hued corrugated houses and artists setting up their canvases. Dancers take center stage on the corners ready to perform for the passing tourists near the crafts market. The aroma of cappuccino emanates from the cafés in Recoleta amidst the shading tilos trees. You venture to a wine-tasting shop in the Abasto, one of the largest shopping centers in the city. The structure originally contained a produce market in the late 19th century but now boasts 174 shops spanning four floors. The quiet boutique winery provides you with eight different glasses of wine from across Argentina’s diverse regions for an introduction to the variety of flavors Argentina produces. You reach a sample of the Torrontes, an aromatic white wine providing fragrant scents of rose petals giving way to flavors of white peach and lemon zest. The sweet aroma and dry body derive from the high elevation of the vines located around Salta. In the evening, your dining experience introduces you to the variety of flavors for which Argentina is known, from the deep and hardy barbecue to flaky savory empanadas. By the end of dinner, your attentive guide through the meal teaches you the proper way to brew the Argentine drink, made by measuring half-ounce portions of loose leaf tea, using cool water to preserve the nutrients, and steeping the tea in hot—not boiling—water for up to four minutes until the herbal aroma becomes potent.

dayInfo.title: Mendoza – Transfer to Mendoza for a Welcome Tour in View of the Andes
dayInfo.description: The doors to one of the city’s most famous cafés open in the morning at El Ateneo Grand Splendid, a former theater turned bookstore and café. The books wind along the three-storied rounded design. The café sits on the old stage overlooking the rows of printed books revealing a serene ambiance in which locals read, study, or sip a rich coffee. Your private transfer greets you at the hotel after breakfast and escorts you to Ministro Pistarini International Airport for your flight to Mendoza. The city has a similar atmosphere to Buenos Aires due to the wide avenues shaded by tall, lush trees. The cafes provide a cosmopolitan ambiance with outdoor seating and indulgent aromas. Tranquil fountains trickle and splash in the plazas and the scent of chocolate drifts out of the various chocolateries. You have a private escort from Governor Francisco Gabrielli International Airport to your charming hotel overlooking the grandeur of the Andes to the west beyond the chocolate hue of the pampas. The region is essentially desert, but the lush trees, vibrant gardens, bustling shops, and nearby vineyards juxtapose the desert landscape due to the plentiful irrigation ditches crisscrossing the region carrying meltwater and rainwater from the Andes. Your guide leads you across the city before arriving at Cerro de la Gloria, a small hill crowned by a statue dedicated to the Army of the Andes. The statue commemorates the forces amassed to fight for independence against the Spanish in the 19th century as armies cross the rugged Andean summits as led by General José de San Martin.

dayInfo.title: Mendoza – Explore the Lujan de Cuyo Wine Region with Sample Tastings
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the scent of cream and sugar drifts out of the different ice cream shops around the city competing to create the best desserts for a city serious about its ice cream. Your guide meets you in the hotel lobby eager to introduce you to the famous flavors of Lujan de Cuyo, a winegrowing region most famous for producing the Malbec grapes. You stop at a vineyard opened in 1998 and committed to the development of quality wines in the region rooted in the authenticity of the cultivation process. The vineyard's dedication to keeping the tradition alive resulted in a blend of New World flavors with Old World techniques. You stroll through the vineyards noticing heat of the desert landscape taking shape. The aroma of dry soil drifts upwards from beneath the vines. Your guide explains how the roots help create balanced flavors by absorbing the minerals from the soil. The staff prunes and thins the bushels for optimal sunlight and moisture without adding any artificial substances. In the tasting room, your guide pours a sample of the Malbec. The aroma of black plum, violet, and leather emanate from the glass. The silky texture coats your tongue with fresh acidity and refined tannins resulting in an espresso flavor.

dayInfo.title: Mendoza – Relish the Maipu Region on a Full Day Tour Paired with Lunch
dayInfo.description: The traditions of local wineries around Mendoza often follow the European traditions brought over by immigrants from Spain, France, or Italy during the 19th and 20th centuries, who also carried the vines from their home regions. While traveling through the heart of the Maipu region less than nine miles outside of Mendoza’s city center, the relaxed ambiance is immediately apparent. The trees shading the wide avenues provide a sleepy quality between the vineyards. The first winery you visit maintains the tradition connecting the terroir with the body, as staff toil the soil and trim the bushes across the vineyards sampling quality at every step. Oak barrels hide in the cool air of the subterranean cellar as the wine ages. The slight changes in temperature allow the wine to absorb some of the natural flavors from the barrel by expanding and contracting against the wood. The tasting room also has a cool temperature contrasting the mid-morning heat spreading over the vineyard outside. Your guide pours a sample of the Bonarda. The grapes originated from Savoie, France and have a deep ruby hue. You find the fruity aroma of black cherry, plum, and allspice with hints of tobacco leaf. The lightly smoky flavor contains a touch of sweet figs and chocolate with juicy acidity and smooth finish. The grape delivers lower tannins and more acidity than Malbec, perfect for fans of wines with less oaky qualities.

dayInfo.title: Mendoza – Travel the Pan American Highway Discovering the Andes
dayInfo.description: Before breakfast, you find the buttery, caramelized aroma of medialunas, pastry similar to croissants, filling the dining room accompanied by creamy and frothy cappuccinos. Your guide greets you at the hotel and escorts you into the untamed landscapes traveling along the Pan American Highway connecting Argentina to Chile through the Andean Foothills. The urban charms of Mendoza and the lush greenery of the vineyards quickly fade to the rugged seclusion of the desert scenery spreading to the dramatic rising foothills of the Andes. The white-capped peaks of the mountains on the horizon reflect the distance and immensity of the longest mountain range in the world. You stop in the charming village of Uspallata. The tranquil scenery once used as a stand-in for the highlands of Central Asia for the film Seven Years in Tibet starring Brad Pitt. On the outskirts of the village stand remarkable 18th-century beehive structures erected by Jesuits. The complex originally was constructed to process minerals from the nearby San Lorenzo mines but was also used as offices and storage facilities during the War of Independence. The climax of the tour takes you to a prime lookout atop Aconcagua, the tallest mountain in the Americas at nearly 22,850 feet above sea level.

dayInfo.title: Mendoza – Enjoy an Active Survey of Mendoza on a Bike and Wine Tour
dayInfo.description: At breakfast, you sample the delicious flaky crusts of the medialunas, which pair perfectly with the slight bitter-sweet flavor of a freshly-brewed coffee or the herbaceous taste of mate. You venture away from Mendoza to reach a quiet village known for its tree-lined streets, lush rows of vineyards, and stunning views of the Andes. Your guide meets you at a small shop in the heart of town before you set out through the countryside on the paved and unpaved roads along the outskirts of Mendoza. The scent of dried soil blends with the herbaceous scent of the trees. You can travel through the vineyard with a guide and taste the struggling grapes, which helps fortify the flavors from the mineral-rich soil. Like many of the vineyards you’ve visited in Mendoza, the winery focuses on traditional methods for production including handpicking the grapes. The bushels are stored in cold or low-temperature rooms depending on the heat of the soil to help keep the conditions optimal for avoiding oxidation. They store the barrels in a cellar without losing the natural humidity before storing the wines in a temperature-controlled room holding up to 400,000 bottles. Sample a varietal consisting of over 60 percent Malbec and nearly 40 percent Cabernet Sauvignon for a distinct combination of French oak and licorice aromas with soft tannins, in addition to a velvety texture.

dayInfo.title: Salta – Fly to Salta for an Immersive Cultural Tour of the Colonial City
dayInfo.description: Salta has a sophisticated allure emanating from the colonial architecture, cafes spilling into the plazas, and vibrant folk music filling the dance clubs and restaurants across the city. You fly from Mendoza to Salta’s Martin Miguel de Güemes International Airport, where your private escort provides a quick transition to your gorgeous hotel at the heart of the bustling city. The streets retain their design from the 1580s with charming cobblestones winding beneath towering palm trees and the main square of Plaza 9 de Julio hosting the neoclassical Catedral Basilica de Salta. Your tour of the city encompasses the dynamic history of the city in its celebration of preserved colonial architecture, Hispanic culture, and Indigenous heritage. Your guide introduces you to the empanadas of Salta, also known as “empanadas Salteñas.” The default flavor of any Salteña empanada is ground beef with potatoes, scallions, and hardboiled egg with a flaky, baked exterior. A tomato and ají pepper sauce accompanies the empanadas for a layer of citrus and spice. Your guide leads you into the fascinating Pascha, the Museum of Indigenous American Art. The galleries display remarkable works of art and culture juxtaposing archeological discoveries with contemporary works from around the continent representing a wide view of Andean culture.

dayInfo.title: Cafayate – Indulge in Wines Touring the High-Altitude Vines of Cafayate
dayInfo.description: The morning view from Cerro San Bernardo provides a different perspective of the city at 3,431 feet above sea level. The gondola ferries locals and visitors to the summit for fabulous panoramic views where people enjoy picnics or basking in the cool breeze at sunset. You travel outside of Salta for the day en route to Cafayate amid the “Puna,” a grassland ecoregion of the high Central Andes. The grassland occurs between 10,500 feet and 11,155 feet. The aroma of alpine herbs swirls in the air beneath the lingering image of the snowcapped peaks. Upon reaching Cafayate, you notice the small-town feel supported by the mixture of colonial and baroque architecture from the 19th century. The mid-ground of verdant vines juxtaposes the arid rocky landscape you traveled through at the Quebrada de las Conchas and continues to juxtapose the soaring mountainous terrain in the background. You stop at a small family-operated bodega known for producing celebrated Torrontes grown at 5,577 feet above sea level and produced with hand-operated equipment.

dayInfo.title: Salta – Delight in Nature’s Beauty at Hamuhuaca Gorge on a Full Day Tour
dayInfo.description: The morning in the high-altitude Andean plains has a cold bite quickly warming in the returning sunlight. The scent of freshly brewed coffee brings warmth to the dining room. The herbaceous aroma of steeping mate accompanies the scent of baking media lunas. You leave behind Cafayate and reach Quebrada de las Conchas, an imposing orange rock ascending against the edges of the valley. Massive tectonic movements over 2 million years created the valley and the surrounding geological forms including the smooth, reddish sedimentary rocks of the Amphitheatre. Once in Jujuy, you find a charming city home to the largest population of indigenous peoples out of any in Argentina. Spanish settlers founded the city in 1593 retaining solidarity with its indigenous citizens or communities known for existing on the margins. The cathedral was erected in the 18th century and features a shimmering baroque pulpit laminated in gold. While no one knows who crafted the masterful feature, some historians believe local artisans erected the piece after training under a European master.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Return to Buenos Aires and Enjoy an Evening Tango Show
dayInfo.description: The bell of Iglesia San Francisco rings out in the morning above the striking colors of the magenta and yellow façade. The interior host’s images of Christianity’s history including a figure of baby Jesus. After breakfast, a private transfer leads you to the airport for your return to Buenos Aires. The city retains a vibrant movement around the distinct neighborhoods. The antique shops in San Telmo overlook the quiet plazas filling the tables and chairs of popular cafes. The Colón Theater reflects the importance of performance at the center of Buenos Aires inside the grand architecture of the design erected in 1908 hosting great performances over the years by Toscanini, Stravinsky, and Pavarotti. In the evening, you attend a tango show in the historic heart of the San Telmo district, inside a restaurant first opened in the 1920s. The tables face the elevated stage making the rooms feel like a hidden, intimate cabaret. When the music starts, the rhythm pulsating from the dancers’ footsteps captivate you. The move in tandem nearly connected emerging from the stage and into the audience, and along the bar showcasing the sensual touch combined with intense focus.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Depart for Home
dayInfo.description: The returning morning light spreads over the blossoming steel and aluminum frame of the Floralis Genérica, a flower sculpture rising out of a rippling pool in the Plaza de las Naciones Unidas. The creative design reflects in the pool, glints in the sun, and closes each evening while emitting a ruby glow. At breakfast, you can enjoy a hardier meal of eggs and toast but prefer to indulge once more in the sweet and buttery media lunas balanced by the slight bitterness of freshly steeped mate. Your private transfer greets you at the hotel in Recoleta and escorts you to Ministro Pistarini International Airport for your flight home.

tourName: Family Adventure: Highlights of Argentina
placesVisited: Buenos Aires, El Calafate, Iguazú Falls
generalInfo: From a sensational trail winding through the jungles around Iguazu Falls to the captivating glint of The Perito Moreno Glacier, your customizable 10-day family tour of Argentina will capture the highlights of the landscape and culture, as it embraces the passion for discovery and the spirit of family fun. Unique neighborhoods, vibrant tropical wildlife, mountainous views, and impressive gauchos accentuate each moment capturing the splendor of your family adventure in Argentina.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Arrive in Buenos Aires with an Introduction to Palermo
dayInfo.description: The famous city of Buenos Aires represents a historic elegance and captivating ambiance that is reminiscent of the renowned Western European cities like Paris and Vienna. Your guide will meet your family in the hotel lobby and will be eager to introduce you to the history and ambiance of Palermo, which is one of the city’s most unique barrios . While you listen to the fascinating evolution of the neighborhood and learn about the architectural design, the kids will participate in a scavenger hunt. As you walk through the area, you may find the aroma of coffee drifting from the cafés.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Experience Buenos Aires on an Immersive Tour
dayInfo.description: After exploring the neighborhoods of the city, you will continue to the playful “Forbidden Not to Touch” Museum, where curious families can discover the thrills of spinning wheels, pulling weights, mixing liquids, and generating electricity. The motto of the museum encourages the kids to have a hands-on experience where they will discover the connection between light and music. You will meet a local family at the end of the day and enter their home to discover the authentic flavors of Argentina. They will prepare typical, delicious Argentinian cuisine such as empanadas, asado, and tasty Argentinian wine.

dayInfo.title: Puerto Iguazu – Tour the Iguazu Forest
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, your private transfer will escort your family to the airport for your flight to Puerto Iguazu, a city located on the border between Paraguay and Brazil. Nature will remain the biggest attraction in the region like the powerful waters of Iguazu Falls. The excitement will grow when you speed through the treetops on a zipline excursion that will have you traveling upwards of 65 feet above the forest floor. You will be able to hear the crashing sounds of water from a nearby waterfall as it cascades down the foothills.

dayInfo.title: Puerto Iguazu – Explore Argentina’s Iguazu National Park
dayInfo.description: You will travel with your private guide to the entrance of Iguazu National Park in Argentina where you will discover the sensational complex that overtakes 261 square miles of protected land and water. Your guide will offer insight into the history of the falls’ formation as well as the surrounding natural beauty of the rainforest. You will take the train to the walkways that lead from Cataratas station for a sweeping view of the waterfall’s dramatic power at Garganta del Diablo, where the 270 smaller falls converge in a horseshoe shape that drops nearly 270 feet with an epic roar.

dayInfo.title: Puerto Iguazu – Discover Iguazu Falls from the Brazilian Side
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, your guide will take your family across the border and into Brazil to explore the Brazilian side of Iguazu Falls, which possesses the best panorama. As you enter the park, you will hear a guttural howl echoing through the trees. Your guide will help to calm the kids who worry about the possibility of a jaguar, and instead, will inform the family about the active howler monkeys in the park. Your guide will offer more insight into the topography and natural history of the region, using the surrounding rainforest canopy for tangible examples.

dayInfo.title: El Calafate – Fly to Patagonia’s El Calafate
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, your private transfer will escort you to Cataratas del Iguazú International Airport for your flight to El Calafate in Patagonia. The town is located less than 50 miles away from the famous landscape of Los Glaciares National Park. The scent of chocolate will wander from the charismatic artisan shops and ice creameries at the heart of town. You will reach your gorgeous accommodations on a private estancia inside the borders of Los Glaciers National. The remainder of the day will be at your family’s leisure to enjoy the comforts, hospitality, and activity of an authentic Argentine ranch.

dayInfo.title: El Calafate – Traverse the Marvels of Los Glaciers National Park
dayInfo.description: Your guide will introduce your family to the magnitude of the landscape, beginning at Perito Moreno Glacier, which is the third-largest glacier in the world. The captivating image will showcase the power and prestige. A walkway that overlooks the lake and glacier will allow you to absorb the massive proportions of the glacier. Scenic boats will glide across the lake and become dwarfed by the massive wall of ice that will capture the imaginations of your entire family. For a deeper adventure, your family can step onto the rugged and undulating surface of the glacier with an ice hiking tour.

dayInfo.title: El Calafate – Enjoy your Estancia with your Choice of Adventure
dayInfo.description: The day is at your leisure but for a family-friendly excursion, you can mount a horse and follow your guide along the trails as they wind through the vast grassland. The empty terrain will blend into the rising hills that are filled with evergreen trees and glassy turquoise rivers. The horses will splash along the riverbanks as you traverse the abras , which are the hidden spaces between the forest and mountains. Your guide will help you find the perfect view of the landscape that will be surrounded by pristine lakes, forest, and mountain ranges of Argentina’s Patagonia.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Return to Buenos Aires with the Day at your Leisure
dayInfo.description: You will make your way to the airport for your flight out of El Calafate and away from Patagonia and return to the bustling streets of Buenos Aires. You will relax in the comforts of your hotel with the remaining day at your family’s leisure to enjoy the city. The pink hue of the presidential palace known as Casa Rosada will be visible from the edge of the street as it crowns the nineteenth-century, central square of the Plaza de Mayo. A great experience for your entire family is to attend a soccer game, especially when the Boca Juniors play.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Depart to Home
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the doors to the renowned former theater of El Ateneo Grand Splendid will open, which was converted into a stunning bookstore with a café situated on the stage. The kids will enjoy sharing their favorite moments from the trip, ranging from the horseback ride through the pampas to the getting drenched on the walkways circling the lower-levels of Iguazu Falls. Your private transfer will meets the family in the hotel lobby when you are ready, and will escort you to Ministro Pistarini International Airport for your flight home.

tourName: Family Friendly Buenos Aires & Iguazu Falls: Cooking, Art & Soccer
placesVisited: Buenos Aires, Iguazu Falls, San Antonio de Areco
generalInfo: Your 8-day family-friendly Argentina tour promises the thrill of centuries-old tunnels hidden beneath feet and the excitement of 60,000 soccer fans cheering for their favorite team. Follow the powerful steps of tango. Embrace the sounds of crashing water echoing from Iguazu Falls. Your tour will introduce the family to vivacious traditions, enchanting landscapes, and passionate culture experienced in daily life from dancing to cooking, art to soccer.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Enjoy a Familial Welcome in Buenos Aires
dayInfo.description: The beauty of Argentina can be summed up in the variety of Buenos Aires. Wide avenues grace the city center. The greenery of La Palermo speaks to the landscape and love of cowboy culture outside of the commercial capital of the country. Mansions and artist colonies spring up in the 47 barrios (neighborhoods), each one carrying the banner of a definitive characteristic that has defined the neighborhood. Fashionable boutiques fill the windows of Avenida Santa Fe. When your family arrives at Ministro Pistarini International Airport, your transfer quickly greets you. Once inside the city, the grandeur of the past and vibrancy of the present come into focus. The aroma of chocolate and freshly baked alfajores calling from jovial cafes. The pearled, neoclassical façade of the Metropolitan Cathedral overlooks the Plaza de Mayo. The city has something to captivate the entire family, from tango dancers to painters, museums dedicated to writers to sports fanatics celebrating the triumphs of the Boca Juniors soccer team. When you arrive at your accommodation in the luxurious neighborhood of La Recoleta, the family settles into the quiet and opulent comforts.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Find the Secrets and Charms of Buenos Aires
dayInfo.description: In the morning, locals filter into cafes and linger at tables with cups of freshly pressed coffee. The aroma of chocolate and pastries filters out of the bakeries and cafes. At breakfast, you can indulge like a local, sipping on your coffee, nibbling on the buttery dough of an empanada, and enjoying a fresh squeezed orange juice. Your guide meets the family at the hotel after breakfast ready to introduce you to the city at large. When you reach the neighborhood of San Telmo, you notice the cobblestone walkways and elegant buildings lining the streets. An antique bookstore embodies the historic character of the neighborhood, selling books in a number of languages. You follow your guide across the cobblestones, past the 18th-century arcade now housing boutique shops and an antique market, and into the labyrinth of subterranean tunnels encompassing 32,291 square feet underneath the city. The network dates back to the 16th century during the Spanish exploration of Argentina. The hidden heart of the city’s oldest barrio is underneath the mansions of El Zanjon. When you step into the cavernous space, the cool, damp air is an immediate change from the warm sunlight of the city. A vaulted ceiling covers the long corridor, perforated by display cabinets holding antique utensils found during the historic excavation and restoration of the stone passageways. The kids jump at the chance to explore the subterranean regions of the city. This exploration makes Buenos Aires a true adventure.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Visit the Neighborhoods of Buenos Aires
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the display cases of the chocolatiers fill with newly formed decorations exuding elegance and delectableness. The kids spend breakfast sharing their favorite moments from the previous day, which tend to revolve around the tunnels in San Telmo and the vibrancy of the buildings in the neighborhood of La Boca. The city celebrates its street art, and you may find images of the 2022 World Cup team or Messi decorating hidden corners of the distinct neighborhoods during your tour. Your guide meets you at the hotel ready to escort the family through the city on a private bike tour. Bike lanes wind through the city, coursing beneath shady trees and traveling beside historic buildings. Your guide leads you on a fantastic route that takes in the exuberance of the city’s past and the jovial atmosphere of the present. The city’s second oldest plaza, Plaza Dorrego, dates back to the 18th century. Caravans used the space as a stop when bringing supplies to the city from across Argentina. Cafes have street-side seating with umbrellas casting refreshing shade over the tables. In the neighborhood of your hotel, that of La Recoleta, you can visit the famous and historic cemetery. The grounds were hallowed in the 18th century by a Franciscan convent and have since been filled with mausoleums, with many famous Argentines throughout history. The marble features create a grid-like design. Your guide explains the importance of the culture that coincides with the cemetery, with many Argentines placing equal weight to a loved one’s birthday and death-day. You follow your guide through the paths and arrive at one of the most internationally renowned figures in the cemetery, Evita Perón. The kids are enthralled with the unique ambiance and culture found on your city tour.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Explore Argentina’s Soccer Culture in Buenos Aires
dayInfo.description: The family has discovered the true beauty of each neighborhood in Buenos Aires, and taken an interest in the variety of culture packed inside such a vibrant city. After breakfast, your guide will lead you back to the La Boca neighborhood to visit the renowned Bombonera stadium, home of the Boca Juniors football club. The stands shine blue and yellow as they look down on the pristine field, representing one of the world’s most emblematic stadiums. During a game, the cheers and songs from the crowd can spill out of the arena and onto the streets of the neighborhood, known for the cheering effect nicknamed “the twelfth man,” which turns the unique design into an unforgettable visceral experience. A mural by Quinqueal Martin depicts the team’s founders selecting the club’s distinctive colors. Inside the Boca Juniors Museum, you can trace the history and connection of the club to greater Argentina, representing one of the country’s most important teams. The collection of trophies may glint under the room’s lighting demonstrating the deeply rooted love of the sport with the neighborhood, city, and country dating back to the club’s founding in 1905. The kids may also see the large mural of Diego Maradona, one of the team’s most notable alumni featured in the hall of fame.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Experience the Cowboy Traditions
dayInfo.description: When morning rises over Buenos Aires, you find the buttery aroma of empanadas and the rich scent of chocolate familiar and comforting. Today, you step away from the city once again, this time venturing to the traditional town of San Antonio de Areco, located approximately 72 miles northwest of Buenos Aires. Lush farmlands encircle the pleasant town. The peaceful atmosphere and historic, colonial streets welcome the family with open arms. The 18th-century allures remain, not just in the preserved culture of the Spanish descendants born in the New World, but in the traditions of the Gauchos. Artisans craft saddles and forge exceptional silverwork. Cowboys from all over the region promenade their horses down the cobbled streets during the November festival. Puente Viejo, the Old Bridge, was erected in the 19th century across the Rio Areco forming the pathway to the north. The parish church decorates the edge of the historic Plaza Ruis de Arellano. A barbecue provides the scent of slowly cooking meat sweeping across the fields. You may find your kids playing soccer in the open green spaces with local children calling out their favorite player from the World Cup team between marveling at the horses and cowboys.

dayInfo.title: Iguazu Falls – Visit the Brazilian Side
dayInfo.description: Before the city bubbles to its normal active nature, your private transfer meets the family at the hotel and escorts you to Ministro Pistarini International Airport for your flight to Iguazu. The town of Puerto Iguazu sits on the confluence of the Rivers Paran and Iguazu. The family notices the remarkable contrast in the city, no longer feeling like Argentina, and instead emerging a more exotic and tropical atmosphere. The town borders both Brazil and Paraguay. Your private transfer meets you at the airport and, after a brief visit to the hotel, leads you across the border of Brazil to visit the panoramic view of the Cataratas do Iguacu, also known as Iguazu Falls. The national park is more than 450,000 cars in size and was listed as a Unesco heritage site in the 1980s. The Brazilian side of the park offers you a panoramic view of the falls, taking in the mystic qualities and unparalleled natural power of the 8,858-foot wide semicircle. You can hear the power of the falls in the epic roar of the water crashing against the rocks and river cascading more than 236 feet. Rainbows form in the mist making the kids as excited as when they first set eyes on the natural beauty of the falls.

dayInfo.title: Iguazu Falls – View the Argentinian Spectacle
dayInfo.description: The tropical climate of Iguazu brings a temperate air to the morning. A light breeze rustles the palm trees. Large toucans flutter in the treetops hidden by the lush greenery. At breakfast, the kids open up fresh pineapple and mango. You sip on decadent organic coffee farmed and processed in Argentina and Brazil. After breakfast, your guide takes you to the Argentine side of Iguazu Falls, inside Iguazu National Park. The park encompasses 212 square miles of protected land and was established in 1934. Although the park showcases the grandeur of the same falls, the difference between the Brazilian and Argentinian parks are like night and day. Trails and walkways wind through lush trees, both above and alongside the Iguazu and Parana Rivers. Butterflies linger on leaves. Some walkways lead closer to the falls offering the family a view of the cascade and the river below. At that moment, the mist swells upwards and coats the family in fresh water as if you had all jumped into the river. The kids laugh uncontrollably as their shirts stick to their skin.

dayInfo.title: Iguazu Falls – The Rush of It All
dayInfo.description: The morning is slow-paced and allows the family time to enjoy your remaining time in Argentina. Birds call through the dense vegetation. The kids think back on their favorite moments over the past week with ardor, commenting on the tango dances and being soaked by the waterfall. An animal hospital and rehabilitation center near the edges of the forest help endangered species and injured animals return to full health. You can often hear the monkeys howling at first light and the macaws twittering. After breakfast, your private transfer greets the family at the hotel and escorts you to the Ministro Pistarini International Airport for your flight home. Sometimes, no matter how long your vacation is, it never seems long enough.

tourName: Highlights of Argentina Tour
placesVisited: Buenos Aires, Ushuaia, El Calafate, Puerto Bandera
generalInfo: Water tumbles over towering cliffs stretching for miles and the sea air blows across the straits and channels that tested even the most daring of explorers. Enormous ice walls groan and shriek under the demands of a constantly shifting world, and the sun touches down over another bustling day in an inimitable world capital. It’s just another day in Argentina, but this highlights of Argentina tour will be unlike anything you’ve ever experienced.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires - Starting Your Adventure in Argentina’s Arresting Capital
dayInfo.description: Early this morning, you land on the outskirts of Buenos Aires, the Paris of Latin America, and one of the great capital cities in the entire world. A private driver will be waiting at the airport to transfer you to your luxurious and elegant hotel, where you can relax from your long journey before hitting the streets of this magical metropolis. This afternoon, you’ll get an expertly guided tour around some of the most historic and fascinating sites in this astounding city. Begin at the famous Plaza de Mayo, surrounded by the colonial-inspired Cabildo, the Parisian façade of the City Hall, the gorgeous pink hue of the Casa de Gobierno and the Classical portico and soaring dome of the Metropolitan Cathedral. Make your way down the famed Avenida 9 de Julio and take in the impressive Teatro Colon, Argentina’s national opera house and one of the premier concert venues on the planet. Then, make your way to some of the outer barrios (neighborhoods) of this spectacular city. You’re sure to fall in love with the stately elegance of Palermo, the liveliness and joie de vivre of La Boca, and the timeless class of La Recoleta, highlighted by the opulent and ornate cemetery that is among the most beautiful of its kind. This evening, head to La Ventana, one of the city’s renowned tango clubs, where you’ll enjoy some of the greatest dancers on the globe, as well as supremely talented musicians and singers, all while enjoying the finest Argentine cuisine and sipping the best Argentine wines.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires - Turning North to a Natural Wonder
dayInfo.description: Prepare to leave the concrete jungle for a world unlike any other as you head for the borderlands of Argentina and an encounter with amazing Iguazu Falls, one of the Earth’s crowning natural marvels. A private driver will escort you to the airport in Buenos Aires, and one will be waiting for you when you arrive in Iguazu, ready to transport you to your truly peerless accommodations in the heart of this protected natural preserve. You can practically see the falls from your bedroom window, and you’re sure to be surrounded with the unmatched grandeur and glories of the countryside.

dayInfo.title: Iguazu Falls - The Argentine Side of Inimitable Iguazu
dayInfo.description: Your first foray into Iguazu is a journey you’ll never forget, as the Iguazu and Parana Rivers conjoin to form one of the most spectacular natural environments in the world. Declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site more than 30 years ago, Iguazu Falls is home to a number of impressive cataracts and a wide array of diverse flora and fauna, which you’ll get to experience first-hand while being led by a knowledgeable and friendly guide. Begin at the Visitor’s Center, where you’ll board a train that will take you up into the heart of the Falls, where the roiling water fills the air with a fine mist and where the scenery is as lush as a tropical rain forest. You’ll wind your way through well maintained footpaths and get an up-close glimpse of the Falls from a number of perfectly perched lookout points, ogling at the more than 250 cascades that tumble to the depths below. You’ll continue on by train to the “Garganta Station,” where you’ll disembark and take a half-mile hike until reaching the highlight of the park, the monstrous and aptly-named Devil’s Throat. This is where nearly 50 percent of all the water in Iguazu tumbles over a precipice stretching for more than half a mile and descends nearly three hundred feet to the placid pools below. The evening sees you back in the hotel for a delicious and memorable dinner.

dayInfo.title: Iguazu Falls - Trekking Down to the Ends of the Earth
dayInfo.description: Take this morning to cross over to Brazil for another glimpse of immaculate Iguazu, getting a sense of the overwhelming size and majesty of the Falls as the colors gleam off the tumbling water. Here, the blues of the river turn pulsing white, the green trees and shrubs hide the brightly colored foliage of birds and small mammals, and everywhere the sky gives way to the proliferation of rainbows, setting the entire scene in a prismatic spectrum that is unlike any other place on the planet. After this foray into Brazil, you’ll be taken to the airport in Puerto Iguazu. You will head far to the south, where the Pacific Ocean meets the Atlantic and where a young naturalist named Charles Darwin once observed the abundant wildlife that calls the waters and lands of the Tierra del Fuego home. You arrive at Ushuaia, widely regarded as the southernmost city on the globe, where a friendly driver will be waiting to take you to your astounding accommodations here at land’s end. You’ll be treated to a delicious and hearty dinner before setting off to bed, anxious for tomorrow’s expedition in this rugged and romantic region.

dayInfo.title: Ushuai - An Unforgettable Day in Tierra del Fuego
dayInfo.description: A filling breakfast gives you plenty of fuel for adventuring, and you set out this morning for the magnificent Tierra del Fuego National Park, an expansive stretch of more than 155,000 acres that is home to some of the most breathtaking scenery you could ever imagine. The plants and animals that are endemic to the region are varied and fascinating, from fire bushes and beech trees to black-necked swans, Magellanic woodpeckers, the southern river otter and the South Andean deer. Nowhere is this beauty quite as evident as at Lapataia Bay, the southernmost point of South America and a region of pristine natural wonders. Lapataia Bay also has a vast array of archeological artifacts from civilizations that lived here centuries ago. Following lunch, you’ll go on the sailing voyage of a lifetime on the Beagle Channel, which separates the mainland from an archipelago of islands that forms the far south of South America (and, indeed, the world). Cruise past Ushuaia and Puerto Williams, the two settlements vying for the title of “southernmost city in the world,” and catch a glimpse of the iconic Les Eslaireurs lighthouse, a remotely controlled lighthouse painted in a striking red-white-red pattern set amidst the incomparable scenery of far south Patagonia. On your way back, you’ll make your way past colonies of penguins and groups of sea lions before ending your day back in Ushuaia.

dayInfo.title: Ushuai - The Pristine Lakes of Patagonia
dayInfo.description: Today, set out for the splendid lakes of the region , from the impeccable setting of Fagnano Lake – where the Andes rise impossibly from the low plains surrounding the azure waters – to the verdant surroundings of Lago Escondido, a narrow, snakelike rush of blue that is translated as “Hidden Lake.” You’ll find yourself in a deep communion with nature, witnessing all of her amazing beauty and holding your breath as the sun creeps up the southern sky, bathing the land in warmth and light. Whether you are a nature lover or city slicker, outdoorsman or couch commando, this is sure to be one foray into the Great Outdoors that will leave you longing for more. The afternoon sees you back in Ushuaia, where you’ll spend one more evening enjoying this unforgettable locale.

dayInfo.title: El Calafate - From the Land of Fire to a World of Ice
dayInfo.description: Venture back inland to experience the crowning marvels of one of the largest ice fields on the planet as today sees you journeying to El Calafate. This quaint and charming town is the jumping off point for some of Argentina’s best natural adventures, from the massive glaciers of Perito Moreno and Upsala to the soaring peaks of Cerro Chalten and Cerro Torre. A private driver will be waiting for you at the airport and will transfer you to your charming hotel, where you can drop off your luggage and explore the city. The Glaciarum is a fine museum dedicated to the science and history of glaciers, from their composition to the stories of the brave men and women who have spent their lives exploring and studying these stupendous formations.

dayInfo.title: El Calafate - Exploring Incredible Perito Moreno
dayInfo.description: Today is spent learning all about the immense and inimitable Perito Moreno Glacier, a central formation in the Southern Patagonian Ice Fields and a singular example of the profound beauty of ice. Reaching across an area nearly one hundred square miles, Perito Moreno is one of only three glaciers in all of Patagonia that is still growing, and it’s also uniquely susceptible to dramatic ruptures, as portions of the glacier’s wall drop precipitously into the sea below with an audible crack. You’ll find exploring the area easy and safe, as all the trails are clearly marked and expertly maintained, and you’ll be truly astounded with how close you can get to these immense structures. You’ll hear the gentle sighing and sharp splits as the glacier moves and reacts to the world around it, and you’ll be awe-inspired by the beryl blue waters and romantic glacier caves that fill your vision and offer a truly out-of-this-world experience. You’ll even find the journey back to El Calafate rewarding, as you pass through a stunning landscape brimming with darling and delightful species of exotic wildlife.

dayInfo.title: El Calafate - A Trip to Upsala and Onelli Bay
dayInfo.description: Turn south on your final day in Argentina, heading for the shores of Lago Argentina and the environs of Puerto Bandera, where you’ll jump on a catamaran that will take you within meters of the outstanding Upsala Glacier , the largest continental glacier in the entire Southern Hemisphere. Covering an area of more than 200 square miles and soaring up to 260 feet above the ocean’s surface, Upsala is sure to captivate and amaze you. The scenery of Onelli Bay completes the panorama in heart-stopping fashion. Be sure to bring your camera, as this part of the world offers photo opportunities that you won’t reproduce in a thousand lifetimes. Return to El Calafate for the afternoon, and spend the evening living up the last bit of Argentine life.

dayInfo.title: El Calafate - The End of Your Argentine Adventure
dayInfo.description: Today, a driver will take you to the airport at El Calafate with plenty of time to board the plane that will return you home. From the banks of the Rio de la Plata, to the stupendous Iguazu Falls, from the channels and straits that mark the edge of the South American continent at Tierra del Fuego, to the astounding Perito Moreno and Upsala Glaciers, this is sure to be a vacation that will send you into paroxysms of joy and leave you in undeniable awe of the marvelous power of nature.

tourName: History, Culture & Wine of Chile and Argentina Tour
placesVisited: Buenos Aires, Mendoza, Santiago
generalInfo: From murals decorating the walls of a Santiago barrio (neighborhood) to tango dancers moving passionately along cobblestone streets in Buenos Aires, this tour introduces you to the diverse lifestyles encompassing the pleasures of the plains, the splendors of the mountains, and the flavorful wines of Mendoza. Watch gauchos , South Americans cowboys, traipse across the plain and race one another around the corral. Sample decadent chocolate treats and delight in the vibrant morning rush at the central market. Your customizable tour immerses you in Argentine and Chilean history and culture, creating a captivating experience of a lifetime.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Vibrant Lifestyle and Welcoming Streets
dayInfo.description: Buenos Aires is a city that enchants visitors from around the world with majestic music and incomparable style, European charm, and Latin American confidence. Your flight lands at Ministro Pistarini International Airport where your private transfer meets you upon arrival. Shades of tango fill the city’s folklore and decorate the art galleries and streets. Cosmopolitan cuisine decorates restaurant windows amidst the traditional pleasures of juicy steak and flaky empanadas. Locals linger in cafes sipping glasses of wine or freshly brewed coffee, enjoying the refreshing breeze rustling the shading trees. Antique stores in the San Telmo neighborhood spill into the small plazas, representing the layers of history for which the city is known. You settle into the pleasures of your centrally located hotel, easily accessing the boutique and avant-garde shops of Palermo or the cobblestone walkways framed by lavish window displays along Calle Florida. The remainder of the day is at your leisure to enjoy the culture of Buenos Aires adorning the streets in the shape of blanketing murals or emanating from the cafes in the enticing aroma of freshly baked aflajores. The Xul Solar Museum provides a unique introduction to the city by way of the artistic inventions, paintings, and captured dreams of Agustin Alejandro Schulz Solari. The galleries, located in the artist’s former apartment, preserve the library of 3,500 books, along with the mystic paintings depicting floating cities and winged horses, providing a perfect backdrop to enter into the majesty of Buenos Aires.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – The Proper Steps
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the enticing scent of fresh-baked cakes and pastries fills the dining room of Ninina Bakery. The decadent aroma of coffee accompanies the buttery cookie and caramel-like filling of the alfajores filling the display case. After breakfast, your guide meets you at the hotel, eager to lead you along the streets to view the mixture of historic charms and contemporary culture, which continues to draw visitors from around the world. You begin in the colorful neighborhood of La Boca, celebrated for the pastel walls of the corrugated homes overlooking the outdoor cafes set out on cobblestone streets. Dancers perform tango outdoors, clapping their hands to the beat and pressing close to their partner in an expression of indefinable passion. Artists capture the dance moves amidst the classic homes with watercolor paintings. The neighborhood of Palermo calls to expats and vacationers, along with growing numbers of portenos , locals of Buenos Aires, due to the boundless cafes and growing restaurants, celebrated museums and chic galleries. Tree-lined streets shade the cobblestone walkways, and Spanish colonial houses stand beside former warehouses that have been converted to house artisanal markets and shops. Vendors along the open-air market in Plaza Serrano offer locally produced olive oils and handcrafted dresses. After exploring the depths of lifestyles inside a variety of neighborhoods, you make your way to a dance studio to learn the proper steps of tango. Your instructor introduces you to the sound, connecting you to the rhythm of the music, explaining that a focus on your partner is more important than the movement. Each step is meant to elevate the passion between the dance partners, beckoning to each other until reaching the final embrace at the end of the song.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Considering Cowboys
dayInfo.description: The sunlight spreads through the doorway of the former theater in the neighborhood of Recoleta. Locals eagerly enter into the spacious grounds set beneath the soaring dome of the El Ateneo Grand Splendid to enjoy a cup of coffee accompanied by the sight of books lining the shelves and a red velvet curtain decorating the stage. After breakfast, you set out for the plains outside the city. The verdant grassland leads you to a private estancia where cows graze and horses run along the edges of the corral. Gauchos , Argentine cowboys, ride through the plains to return to the country house after a half day's work. The aromas of the rich soil and herbaceous trees blend in the swirling air. The day takes in the exciting and relaxed atmosphere of a neighborhood barbecue, offering horseback rides and a traditional folk show, during which musicians strum their guitars offering the sounds of the countryside. The scent of freshly baked empanadas emanates from the kitchen. A woman offers you the flaky, buttery snack stuffed with savory, meaty filling. Horse-drawn carriages explore the grounds, and the gauchos start a large fire to begin cooking sausages, chicken, and beef over the open flame. The cowboys begin to show off their skills, racing on horseback around the ring, and herding sheep into the corrals. Dirt kicks up along the grass as you cheer for the gauchos running across the estate.

dayInfo.title: Mendoza – In the Land of Vines and Chocolate
dayInfo.description: In the morning, locals from the neighborhood of Palermo head to their favorite cafes to enjoy the unique menu of mouthwatering desserts and coffee flavored treats. The display case fills with chocolate cakes and butter cookies. The scent of waffles and pancakes overtakes the dining room. After breakfast, your private transfer meets you at the hotel and escorts you to the airport for your flight to Mendoza, home of Argentina’s wine growing region. The city bustles beneath leafy avenues and plazas filled with locals enjoying the sunlight. Irrigation ditches run alongside the main roads leading to stunning fountains spouting with balletic water displays. Vines spread across the valley outside the city, until reaching the undulating hills. Your private transfer greets you upon landing at Governor Francisco Gabrielli International Airport, before leading you to a luxurious hotel located near the city center. The remainder of the day is yours to enjoy the enchanting streets of the city, filled with outdoor cafes and elegant restaurants, decadent chocolateries and inviting boutique wine shops. The Andes Mountains loom over the horizon along the town’s western edges. The low-lying plains provide the perfect expanse for the wineries to thrive. Over 150 vendors set up their stands in Plaza Independencia, hosting the daily artisan market. Handcrafted statues and hand-woven garments are displayed next to unique handmade jewelry. The Basilica of San Francisco dates back to the 19th century and contains images of the patron saint who graced the passage of San Martin’s army while crossing the Andes in the early 1800s. Mosaic-tile fountains embellish the Plaza Espana in front of the cathedral façade.

dayInfo.title: Mendoza – Sampling Mendoza
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the sweet aroma of tiramisu and forest fruits emanates from the various ice cream parlors across Mendoza churning the fresh-made ice cream to start the day. At breakfast, you sip a rich cup of coffee before meeting your guide to set out onto the vineyards found on the outskirts of Mendoza. The country roads run between verdant vines and irrigation ditches. Visitors ride bicycles between the wineries, enjoying the view of the green leaves, rolling hills, and snow-capped peaks of the distant Andean range. You stop at your first winery for an introduction into the viticulture and harvesting process in the valley. Your guide provides a brief history of the vineyard, and explains the importance of the vineyard’s segmentations, with the soil in each area offering different flavors and minerals to the grapes. The vineyard overtakes nearly 30 acres and stands at more than 3,400 feet above sea level. After your exploration of the grounds, and visiting the cellars, you enter the tasting room to sample the finished, aged product. Your guide pours a splash into a glass. You breathe in the aromas to find hints of leather, blackberry, and violet. Upon sipping the wine, you notice the silky texture and fresh acidity, leaving layers of espresso flavor on your palate.

dayInfo.title: Santiago – Beneath the Andes Mountains
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the aroma of chocolate returns to Mendoza emanating from the various gourmet chocolateries across town. The fountains continue to trickle with water as the artisan craftsmen open their stands at Feria de Artesanos. Your transfer meets you at the hotel and leads you away from the burgeoning streets of the city en route to Santiago, Chile. The desert plain gives way to the rugged foothills of the Andean range. The dramatic peak of Aconcagua, the highest mountain in South America, draws your eye. The snowcapped peak reaches more than 22,800 feet above sea level. The peak stands solely inside Argentina, with the rolling Andean peaks in the background drawing the border between Argentina and Chile. While viewing Aconcagua, the mountain air has a crisp, cool temperature. The breeze brushes against your cheeks with a slight bite. The valley ridges lead to the rugged foothills beneath a set of glaciers, the largest of which extends for more than six miles. You cross the border and reach Santiago, Chile, settling into the comforts of your luxurious hotel situated near the bustling city center. The cosmopolitan atmosphere reminds you of a smaller Buenos Aires, with skyscrapers imitating the mountain bordering the city to the east. Remarkable museums and celebrated restaurants adorn the leafy streets beside grandiose architecture and pedestrian malls.

dayInfo.title: Santiago – Beyond Bohemia
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the sunlight glints off the towering figure of Sky Costanera, the tallest building in Chile, which reaches a height of nearly 1,000 feet above the bustling streets. Business people venture through the central district ordering strong coffee from fast-paced cafes. In the outlying neighborhoods, cafes decorated with murals and a relaxed ambiance provide university students and artists a place to bask in the aroma of fresh pastries and discuss the passing philosophical trends. Your guide meets you in the hotel lobby eager to lead you through the archaeological splendors of the city beginning at Plaza de Armas, the former city center. The plaza was first founded in the 16th century after the arrive of the Spanish. The 18th-century edifice of the Metropolitan Cathedral of Santiago continues to bring visitors and locals alike to the square. The Spanish baroque architectural elements embellish the stone framework along the archways and tripartite wooden doors. The central fountain celebrates the memory of Simon Bolivar who helped lead the movement for Chilean independence against Spain. You reach the neighborhood of Bellavista and immediately notice the youthful atmosphere drifting out of the colorful buildings. Vibrant murals decorate the walls beneath the cobalt blue walls of Pablo Neruda’s house, known as La Chascona . The nautical themes of the interior décor speak to the chosen color of the paint decorating the exterior walls, which were painted the hues of the sea.

dayInfo.title: Santiago – Truth in Lifestyle
dayInfo.description: Vendors make their way to Mercado Central near sunrise to display the fresh seafood caught earlier and brought inland from the shore. The stalls on the periphery of the market craft traditional home-cooked cuisine the locals enjoy, while the restaurants at the center of the market enjoy the natural light of the central dome. The Museo de la Moda presents a unique perspective on the Western clothing of 20th-century designers, including exhibits displaying John Lennon’s jacket from a 1966 tour and an evening gown worn by Lady Diana in the early 1980s. The culture of the city represents the cosmopolitan lifestyle. Your private transfer meets you in the hotel lobby when you are ready, escorting you to Comodoro Arturo Merino Benitez International Airport for your flight home.

tourName: Kid-Friendly Argentina Vacation: Waterfalls & City Lights
placesVisited: Iguazú Falls, Bariloche, Buenos Aires
generalInfo: During this luxurious 7-day excursion through Argentina, traverse this unique country as a family and be exposed to much of the best that this incredible country has to offer. From the pristine glacial waters of Bariloche’s Lake District to the charming streets of Palermo in Buenos Aires, Argentina fosters the perfect atmosphere for a family getaway. Glide through the sky above the illustrious Iguazu Falls in a private helicopter, listen to the rushing water of waterfalls, indulge in a traditional chocolate-making class in Bariloche, and attend a authentic tango show in Buenos Aires.

dayInfo.title: Iguazu – Experience La Garganta del Diablo
dayInfo.description: You will arrive at the airport in Misiones, where you will be met and transferred to your luxurious accommodation near Iguazu Falls. Once you arrive at your luxury accommodation, you will have ample time to settle in before meeting your knowledgeable guide to embark on your first adventure in Argentina. When you are ready, you will be transferred to La Garganta del Diablo, which is known as one of the most iconic of Iguazu’s many falls. Upon your arrival at this particular waterfall, you will approach the observation deck, which will lead you into the heart of the falls. After you have had sufficient time to explore the falls and take photos as a family, you will be transferred into the town of Misiones, where you can indulge in your first Argentine meal.

dayInfo.title: Iguazu – Thrilling Boat Tour to the Falls
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will enjoy an Argentine breakfast at your hotel before embarking on your adventures in Iguazu. When you are ready, you will indulge in a private helicopter ride that will fly you over the falls. After your thrilling helicopter ride has concluded, you will be transferred to the base of the falls, where you will be provided with the opportunity to experience Iguazu from an entirely new angle. At the base of the falls, you will be guided to various lookout points, which will allow you to stand on incredible observation decks in the heart of the falls. Once you have seen the falls from a series of lookout points, you will board a ferry that will carry you deeper into the falls.

dayInfo.title: Bariloche – Explore the Lake District as a Family
dayInfo.description: Today, you will fly to the charming town of Bariloche, which is known as the “Swiss Alps of South America.” After you have had time to settle in to your suite, you will meet your expert guide in the lobby to begin the day’s adventures. When you are ready, you will board a private yacht for an excursion through the charming Lake District. Throughout your tour, you will be guided on leisurely treks through the extraordinary natural landscape, where you will encounter regional flora and fauna. In the evening, you will transfer to the charming city center of Bariloche, where you will marvel at the intricate German and Swiss-influenced architecture and cultural style that characterizes it.

dayInfo.title: Bariloche – Private Chocolate-Making Class
dayInfo.description: This morning, your family will indulge in a traditional Argentine breakfast before continuing your exploration of Bariloche. When you are ready, your family will be led on a private horseback tour through the vast landscape of Bariloche. In the evening, you will be transferred back to the lovely city center, where you will partake in a wonderful chocolate-making class alongside your family. The chocolate in this region is known as some of the best in South America, and you will be absolutely charmed by the opportunity to learn how it is made firsthand. During your class, you will be able to sample the delicious fruits of your labor. Afterward, you will have the evening to spend at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Discover the Best of the City
dayInfo.description: Today, you will have an early morning and breakfast before flying to the magnificent city of Buenos Aires. Upon your arrival, you will be transferred to your luxurious accommodation before meeting your expert guide to begin the day’s activities. When you are ready, you will embark on a specially curated tour of Buenos Aires and will experience the city’s top sites and neighborhoods. You will begin your tour with a transfer to the upscale neighborhood of Recoleta, where you will delight in a private tour of the Recoleta Cemetery. From there, you will continue to the city center, where you will experience the bustling life that characterizes this city. Afterward, you will arrive in the historic barrio of San Telmo, where you can meander through the lively Feria San Telmo, which is the neighborhood’s open-air market that is always brimming with local vendors and traditional Argentine culture.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Live Tango Show and Gourmet Dinner
dayInfo.description: This morning, your family will indulge in a traditional Argentine breakfast before continuing your exploration of this marvelous city. You will begin with a private transfer to Buenos Aires’ most vibrant neighborhood of La Boca. You will have time to wander through the area at your leisure and to admire the charming shops that are full of handmade products crafted by local artisans. From La Boca, you will be transferred to Bosques de Palermo. You will have ample time to explore the Bosques de Palermo as a family and relax before connecting with your guide to begin your evening’s exciting activities. This evening, you will attend an incredible tango performance that will be accompanied by an Argentine meal and wine pairing.

dayInfo.title: Buenos Aires – Farewell to Argentina
